job_title: Adjunct Professor in Miami, FL
pros: The parking is good, and the faculty members are nice.
cons:
The board makes all the decisions and they show zero appreciation or respect for faculty members and students. It's all about the money and they don't care to hide this anymore. They make decisions shamelessly but don't show their faces. They are always making changes and demanding that faculty do more and more, but they won't pay one more cent for the extra work, EVER. This all started with the pandemic when the Art Institutes consolidated the remaining of its campuses under one umbrella.

Many students are so upset, that they come to class crying, it's heartbreaking... They changed the curricula and all of a sudden they need twice as many credits as they needed before in order to graduate. The school doesn't offer the classes they need to take, so full-time students are put in classes they don't need or classes they are not prepared to take, and we, the professors, have to deal with the mess.

They play with class availability and schedules until the last minute. Students can't organize their quarter because of these constant changes and many times they have to drop a class because the time or day changes and it conflicts with other classes they are taking. This also is an issue because when it happens, professors are not given enough time to prep. There is tons of miscommunication. If you are a professor you may see your assigned class with 16 students and on the first day of class, that number has duplicated.

The administration is a mess. Probably because they fired a lot of people so the people left are juggling a lot of things at once.

Small library.

Everything I've written is things that I've experienced as an Adjunct Professor.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Miami, FL
pros: I absolutely loved my coworkers, the creative environment, and working with creative students. The professors are very invested in their students and will work hard to challenge their creative limits. The location I worked for really does care for the well-being and success of students. As an employee, I always found great constructive feedback from my supervisor and a clear plan on how to improve areas that needed improvement. I can't complain one bit about the work done "on ground". Also, the salary is great, as well as the benefits package. It supersedes other employees in the same industry.
cons: They insist that numbers no longer count, but this is very untrue. Losing a student or no making enough daily dials will eventually cost you your job. There are many uncontrollable elements to ones job there, but it always becomes the fault or failure of the admissions representative. Corporate office makes changes in a weekly, sometimes daily, basis. Also, people are constantly being let go every time they decide their workers are a strain on their budget. The disconnection between the employees in the school and corporate is huge. I think even the managers feel "out of the loop" on many things. Overall, it has become an environment of fear and job insecurity. I was recently laid off, and I am not even sad about it. It is worse to be waiting around for corporate to decide if yours worth the expense or not.

review_title: Loved It! (pre-2012 but only year would let me choose)
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Seattle, WA
pros:
Terrific environment with excited, motivated students, beautiful location and opportunity to work hard and prove yourself. Worked with a fantastic group of like-minded people. The instructors, full time, part time and professional, were enthusiastic and eager to help admissions and the students. Most students were motivated and it's rewarding to see them graduate, go out into the marketplace and use their skills. They're entering very competitive, challenging fields and it's exciting to see them tackle the process of finding jobs. They're getting an education to learn to do something they love and that's hard work and costly.

HR and direct management was constantly encouraging, demanding, staff to use their time off, take full vacations, etc., but the profile of the employees tends to be driven and challenge oriented so many worked long, extra hours. Work hard but definitely work smart and it's great.
cons: Expectations were very high but you know that going in and it was part of the interview process. Lots, lots, lots of phone time contacting prospective students and once enrolled keeping in contact with them to complete the extensive paperwork they need to keep up with. Many students are disillusioned when they interview and find how competitive the marketplace is. There are no guarantees in life and no guarantees in creative fields but they definitely will fail if they don't at least try. There is a substantial--very substantial--cost to this education and they need to be sure they understand it's a business, not glamour and fame.

review_title: Only if you are desperate or need work experience
job_title: Front Desk in Houston, TX
pros: You can make friends with co-workers easily, but be careful.  Friendly environment.  Don't have to use brain power although that is also a con because it makes you a zombie.  Glad I got some full-time work experience.  The students can be sweet, especially the culinary ones who let you taste their food.
cons: They are supposed to rotate working holidays for support staff, but they don't.  And if there is a holiday party, the front desk worker doesn't get to go until they are cleaning up and only gets about 5-10 minutes whereas everyone else had a couple hours off.  Also, supposed to have a set lunch hour, but that never happens.  Lunch hour will be whenever the back up feels like coming to relieve you and that could be 6 and a half hours into your 8 hour shift.  Supposed to get 2 15 minute breaks, but no one will ever tell you that because no one wants to have to cover for you.  Horrible lack of communication even within departments.  No one ever knows what is going on.  People working in the back don't answer the phone or are late or leave early so you have to deal with angry students/parents all day.  If you get up to use the restroom, people freak out- get over it.  Also, the "raise" you get is a little more than a quarter...

review_title: Decent job but not anything you'll be proud of later in life
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Portland, OR
pros:
Great location, fun staff and certain students are truly inspirational. I helped students who have gone on to tremendous careers in motion graphics, animation, fashion, etc. It's really, really cool to see student names in the credits of Thor and Iron Man, or to put on some Adidas sportswear and wonder if I knew the person who designed it

No one ever works more than 40 hours and schedules are at least somewhat flexible
cons:
Guilt. Typical for-profit college where at some point the need for $ conquers the need to be honest with students. Teachers don't fail students they should be failing, and the school basically treats students as a business. I understand that's necessary to a certain extent but students are accumulating $60k + debt when they could have cut their losses way earlier. It's tough to be a part of that

Beyond guilt, I didn't work with many people who were actually trying to accomplish anything substantial. Fresh new ideas were usually met with "well, you can try that if you want." No support ever, though I suppose that's better than "you're not allowed to try anything at all."

In short, the overly corporate environment takes a lot of the life out of this place

review_title: Run...don't walk, AWAY from The Art Institutes
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Dallas, TX
pros: I would love to say something nice about them. But I can't.
cons:
There are WAY too many problems with this place to even consider working there.  First, management has no idea on how to properly manage people.  If you like working in an environment where you are punished for doing your job, then this is the place for you.  If you like working in an environment where your manager manages from a distance and doles out idle threats everyday, then this is the place for you.  If you like working in an environment where  supposedly non-negotiable polices change every single day, then this is the place for you.  Point is that this place is so mis-managed from the top down, that it's no wonder why people (and students included) decide to work/attend somewhere else.

Don't let the 1-star rating fool you.  If I could give a rating of 0 stars, then I would.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Good benefits, each admissions rep has their own office.
cons: You are basically set up to fail from day 1.  The lead distribution is unfair, giving favor to only a couple of senior people.  You are recorded and micromanaged to the max...by every word...literally.  They would take money and an application from any student , and if you could'nt close the student you would have long meetings going over what you said wrong and you need to call in management before the student leaves to help close the deal...remindes me of a car salesman.  High pressure to the point ...if your not making your numbers no vacation...you have to be almost dead to ask for a day off.  I don't think management has much experience in manageing.  If I'm selling an $80,000 Bachelor Degree in Photography, Illustration, ect...it better be in the best interest of the student, and they don't see it like that.  High turn over...they let go 12 people in the last couple of months and now are rehiring once again???  Not surprised.  Go ahead, apply for the position and see the mess for your self at least you will get good benefits and help some students.

review_title: Being Faculty used to be about education...
job_title: Faculty in Costa Mesa, CA
pros:
The only remaining pro is getting through to the students that want to grow and learn.  Working with the students is the only reward you should hope to receive.  

Oh, and it's a teaching schedule, so you can get a couple weeks off twice a year.
cons:
Management is a revolving door.  Many of the staff making schedules for classes don't actually understand course material and how the classes they are offering/not offering impact the students.

Admissions convinces anything with a pulse that they can afford this school and want a degree here - despite an often lack of motivation or aptitude.  This results in many students who have no interest in actually working towards a completed degree and take time away from the students who actually want your guidance.  

Courses are being handed down from corporate in an attempt to homogenize classes.  The result is new course names with fancy buzzwords that don't actually allow basic courses to appropriately lead into intermediate or advanced classes.  Students in advanced classes are often left ill prepared to complete assignments due to this (and the above mentioned scheduling issues).

And don't come here looking for career advancement -  there have not been a pay increase for several years and many of the Department Director jobs have been removed in favor of Corporate handing down department decisions and online registration. 

I could go on, but the short story is that the parent company was bought out by a financial institution and it unfortunately seems that they are looking to milk this system for every penny before the government comes in and regulates it - at the expense of the students and faculty.

review_title: Seemed like a great job in the beginning...
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Austin, TX
pros: Good title, decent pay for this industry.  Speaking to creative individuals, and generally being a part of a close knit college environment.
cons: Because of EDMC's constant financial decline over the last couple years, they have restructured and cut many positions, perks, bonuses, that once made this place a fun/yet challenging work environment.  With upper management unable to show the growth that Corporate needs to see (due to more regulations/scrutiny on for-profit schools, an uncertain economy, and high tuition costs) they have placed blame on every possible admission position at the school level starting with the ADA's on up to the Senior Director (most of which have quit or been fired).  If your quota is not met quarterly they deem it an incompetency of the individual, and put your employment on the line.  No job security.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good Health Benefits, 401k, PTO and decent salary. Every so ofter getting a chance to work with a true Art student. Great location for living in SF.
cons:
Horrible working conditions. Go to the 2nd floor and see The Boiler Room in action! Wait you cant, because they look the admissions door to the public. The current Senior Director of Admissions must be the most unprofessional manger there is. He uses car sales techniques and pressure sales techniques to get students to apply and enroll. Back stabbing, degrading comments, and gender bias are common day practices.

I feel so horrible that I was even part of this for the short period of time that I was. Though I never pressured any students and could sleep at night, I saw and witness many students who could not afford and had no business being at this school get pressured and conned into starting. Only to drop out weeks or months later. Horrible hours, working to late nights and weekends. Sen. Dir. of Adm puts himself first before employees and family.

I think some of the people in the admissions department are very talented and have amazing upside. I sure hope they decide to move on to a better environment and company/school that values true students and education versus quotas for applications and enrollments.  

I understand that needing students helps keep the school afloat, but not at the expense of 18-25yr old students lives that do not belong or afford a $100K Undergrad degree. 

If you have no family, no kids, no integrity, and purely need a stop by job, then the admissions here is the place to be.

review_title: Decent pay, I really liked working there.
job_title: Teacher in North Hollywood, CA
pros:
I worked in the North Hollywood location and the building was nice and centrally located. Free parking VERY nice structure. Matching 401 K, safe environment.

Very dedicated teachers.
cons:
The entire for profit sector misses the point and I don't get it. I cant be any smarter than them but if you create a value proposition, hire full time teachers and pay benefits you have continuity, satisfied instructors who feel supported and will always come back because they feel that they are being treated fairly. Thus in turn leads to satisfied students who recommend the school and drive revenues. Whats so hard about that? As a corporate manager I was always over budget but came in with record revenues on a national scale and I know my formula worked. Not knowing what your income is going to be is ridiculously stressful and if you have to look for other teaching gigs you cant take an Ai class if it is offered and you become less effective. 

You cannot control students attitudes and you play to your audience but as a teacher i think that attendance policies and limits need to be stricter. Stop worrying about revenues and kick the slackers out. The real students will stick it out and get the point.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Seattle, WA
pros: The people can be friendly. They're intelligent, and many have great senses of humor. All of the Assistant Directors of Admissions that I worked with did seem to genuinely care about the kids.
cons: The management is AWFUL. I have never worked in such a cancerous environment. They use emotional and psychological tactics, such as telling employees that other employees are badmouthing them on the floor (which normally isn't true, but it's so devastating that it reaches a reaction of vulnerability that they want). They belittle their employees, publicly announcing numbers (PS- aren't we supposed to be about education here?) in front of all other employees at large meetings in order to push them into action.  Recently they held a meeting and encouraged everyone to go ahead and quit if they weren't serious. The management is completely brainwashed, and absolutely do not have any stock in the employees. The employees are sat down in meetings and told to basically perform, or they're gone. This is a hardcore sales position, and all of the sales is masked in "doing what's best for the student.. isn't education great." Well, it IS great. But not for that price tag, and, in the sake of the employees, not at the sacrifice of their santiy, and complete belittlement. PLEASE be careful!

review_title: Work with amazing people but expect horrible decisions made by the corporate
job_title: Support Staff in Seattle, WA
pros: Great people to work with, great passionate students with dreams. You'll help them get through school and it's a rewarding feeling when you see them graduate and get their dream job.
cons:
You get to work with amazing staff and faculty. The people are great, it's just that corporate tend to make horrible decisions. Like downsizing 20-30 people across nation, and with that extra money, they remodeled the institutes a month later. Or they lay off people who's worked there for over 20 years for no reason- or important people like loan coordinators and people who contact students when their loans are due were laid off so a lot of students were defaulting in their loans. I heard that there were some bullying and harassment going on behind the admissions door- but I never knew what was going on. I guess they're very sales driven and it's cut throat if you don't recruit enough students.

My job was fine. Just the situation around me was tense. There's always war going between Financial aid and Admissions but I guess there will always be conflict between departments wherever you go. Not much room for growth. There's hardly any advancement.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Seattle, WA
pros:
Great views and neighborhood
Some of the faculty really seem to care about the welfare of the students
My co-workers...we were all in this together like captives on a slave ship
cons:
Unrealistic metrics
Excessively high turnover
A negative attitude hangs over the work environment like a fog on Elliott Bay
Managers play favorites and make no bones about it
The "leads" are old lists of people who at one time or another made an inquiry. They can be 10 days or 10 years old. You will continue to call the same people and infuriate them.
Most of the managers do not have a clue. They do not work well with others and are only there to berate people and micromanage them.
There is no work/life balance. It is all about work.
At least two nights each week you are required to work until 8pm
Very few weekends off. There are always Open Houses and other such events to sucker prospects and their families into coming to the campus
Micromanaging 24/7
Wins are not celebrated but those who are failing are called out in front of everyone
Lack of motivation is directly attributable to how people are treated here

review_title: It was a scam for the employees as much as it was for the students.
job_title: Admissions Representative in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Some great people worked there and are still struggling after the lay-off.
cons: I was brought in after the lawsuit settlement to help "redefine the face of the organization" only to be laid-off 7 months later quite abruptly.  The management did not care at all about the lower level employees.  We were dispensable to them.  Due to their mismanagement, an Art School that started in Pittsburgh in 1929 is now a for-profit school that barely has  a presence anywhere.  Who was our biggest investors (we were publicly traded)?  Goldman Sachs and Colin Powell.  Goldman Sachs successfully found a way to take government FAFSA money and put it in their pockets while destroying a young person's future by tricking them into thinking the school had positive gainful employment statistics while they placed you in a fast-food job upon graduation.  I have never felt more guilty in my life than when I worked for EDMC and the Art Institute.  A scam all around.

review_title: If you want a job for less than a year..this is the place for you
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Miami, FL
pros: good benefits, salary starts at $41k a year for Assistant Director of Admissions
cons: To many to mention! You are a number and a number only!! $$$ Talks!! All they care is enrollments because that means money. THIS IS A SALES JOB !!! Trust me I WORK HERE !! Also the TURN  OVER IS HIGH, Out of 26 people in my team only 6 has been there more than a year. The job is simple! YOU ARE A TELEMARKETER!!! You will be on the dam phone all day long, and the rejection is about 98% of all calls you make. The poor students are the victims, The Arts Institutes consist of Degrees and education that anyone can go to YOUTUBE and watch videos and learn for free!!. The cost for a degree...$86K...and when they graduate the salary average will be $12.00 an hour!.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Good benefits- health care, dental, paid time off, 401k.
cons: Micromanaged.  Negative reinforcement.  Was promised a base salary plus commissions when hired yet after I started working, they said they could no longer offer anyone commissions.  The school lets ANYONE enroll as long as they pay their money.  Very HIGH turnover in sales!  Have to work many Saturdays without getting a full day off during the week as originally promised.  So you end up working 6 days a week several weeks out of the month.   If you want to feel appreciated for your hard work and effort, this is NOT the place for you.  You will be treated like you are just a number and a child.

review_title: Think again, unless you're a sales career driven individual!
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Houston, TX
pros: Benefits, a good starting pay
cons: I had no idea that this was a sales position; had I known, I would have never applied or taken the position. The work/life balance is awful, it's very difficult to manage your personal life when you're always at work. You will work late (6pm - 8pm) and Saturdays (6 days a week). High stress and redundant work, as the work is simple but your work days consist of calling people who are or were once upon a time interested in the school. You will have to meet enrollment goals. High micro-management! Our team meets at least once a week for a one on one meeting with a manger and two regular meets to see where our sales goals are. The company is on a budget, there is no room for promotion or salary increases, fyi. No overtime.   High turnover. You'll work holidays and it's very hard to use the nice amount of PTO given to you by the company because of the blackout dates. If you enjoy sales, you may like it. If not, run!!!

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The Art Institute did an adequate job of providing computer labs and most of the necessary computer programs for students to do their work. Most immediate supervisors were genuinely concerned about student success, and understood and worked to provide students with what they needed to succeed.
cons:
While my immediate supervisors were very concerned about student success, it felt like the primary purpose and motivation of the overall organization was to take money from vulnerable and unqualified students by way of federal loans.

This company engaged in the practice of attracting and recruiting students who had little chance of succeeding in a very competitive industry and therefor being able to pay back the substantial student debt they were incurring.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Houston, TX
pros: The people that work there and the paycheck.
cons: Not what they make it seem like during the interview process, once you are hired then you find out how awful of a place it really is. Sitting in a cube for a period of 8 hours or more calling off canceled lists, inquiries from years dating all the way back to 2000. Managers are awful and disrespect you. They hover over you and try to intimidate you by watching your every move. They will listen in on your phone calls to make sure you are being robotic when trying to convince and coerce a student to come in. Then they make you manipulate a student by telling them that they're getting this amazing education when in fact it is a six figure degree you might as well go to a REAL university. A lot of manipulation and conning I don't know how these people and the Institute still exists. Awful place to work! Do not work here is the advice I would give any person looking for a job desperate or not.

review_title: First job out of college, and AiS slapped me in the face at 100mph about how the "real world" was.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Seattle, WA
pros:
Students
I had my own offive at the time.......employees are now in cubicles.
cons:
NSR......weekly meeting to intimidate employees for high sales goals.
This is a cut throat sales position disguised as an education position. Management e ill constantly tell you that you are "changing peoples lives". Well I'm. Older and wiser now, and i know that putting students into thousands of dollars worth of debt is not an honarable way to change a students life.
Nobody tries to get to know you for at least 6 months.....if you make it past that 6 month mark othe employees will start to invest in you......maybee. The turnover is huge.
FA and Admissions have horrible communication. We needed ttem, they needed us, why cant we just figure it out? If a problem between the two departments comes up it wil always be the ADA's fault, so prepare to get yelled at by your director and possibly the. FA director as well.
The school in no way represents. What a hundred thousand dollar education should get you, making student tours eembarrassing.
Gossip.....gossip....gossip.
Stealing students off of random call lists.
Required to continne to call students who have said "no" a dozen times.
This list could go on for days.

review_title: my experience as an Adjunct Instructor
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The people are great. The work atmosphere is professional, warm and friendly. Supervisors are understanding. The students are often motivated and talented. As an instructor you receive support but also freedom to teach how you want.
cons: Pay is on the low side, and as an adjunct I have not been assigned enough classes to make a living. I have been there a year. I started out teaching only one course and and still will start the next quarter teaching only one class. (One quarter I was assigned three courses but then it was back down to one.) Enrollment is down due to the Art Institutes' reputation having suffered a beating in the national media, as well as more general trends in the industry. The future of my particular school (Fort Lauderdale) is uncertain due to our accrediting agency recently having had its license taken away by the Dept. of Education. (However the different locations are not all accredited by the same agency.) We are still accredited as of this writing but the school has a limited time to make alternate plans to receive accreditation from another accrediting body.

review_title: Prepare to not have a life...
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Atlanta, GA
pros: Fantastic benefits, some really great people to work with, and free food on occasion.  Fantastic professors and loved the staff in other departments.
cons: Wow...where to even start.  You can't take any vacation on black listed weeks, and there are a lot of them.  Management fed applications to specific people in order to make it look like you needed to work harder.  There was unfair treatment of various genders in the work place.  I was admonished for wearing red lipstick to work and another co-worker was told he needed to get rid of his facial hair.  I felt like there was always some sort of mind game going on and not a realistic view of the students' ability to pay back tuition of that magnitute in a manner that was true to life.

job_title: Instructor in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: Some of my coworkers were great, some of the students were great and it was in California so the weather was nice most of the time too.  Good benefits if you are full-time.
cons:
You will feel more like a retail sales person then a professional.    Behind the 'we care about our students" marking tag line, the real and only goal is to keep the school churning out as many students as possible to maintain its high profit margin.

Most staff meeting revolve around this principle as an undertone to the topic of the day.  You will be pushed to market the school on a regular basis instead of growing as a professional or focusing on the students needs.   More show then tell.

The place is also a job mill.  The turnover rate is high at all levels.  This is due of the constant waves of lay-offs ignited by a huge lawsuit filed against them by the US Government alleging student loan fraud.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Once you are a seasoned employee the vacation time is very good. 
I truly enjoy helping student, they are the main reason why I stay. Love creative individuals. 
I do not work weekends or late nights
Have 12 paid holidays. 
Hourly wage so get 1.5 for overtime
cons:
No 401k match
Expensive health plans
Company is suffering due regulations brought down by those who didn't do their jobs right at the online school, got fired and then sued the company for it. 
Lot of layoffs of important roles-current employees are doing multiple jobs now.

review_title: Decent pay and benefits, but poor quality working environment
job_title: Career Services in Minneapolis, MN
pros: In my position the salary was fair and reasonable, and we had good benefits.  I really enjoyed my colleagues and the atmosphere among most employees was friendly and collaborative.
cons: The working environment was less than satisfactory.  Rules and policies were applied unevenly across departments and within departments based on the people in management.  In a relatively short period of time the President's position turned over several times and several key management staff were fired along with support staff fired.  Employees were treated as expendable in a "numbers" game to meet recruitment goals.  In a college atmosphere, education was given a back burner to making money.

review_title: I was am instructor at the Art Institute of Dallas: writing classes, teaching, dealing with inadequate technology.
job_title: Instructor in Dallas, TX
pros: The students are eager to learn, interactions are rewarding. You know you are making a difference and what you are teaching will help them enter and grow in their career.
cons:
•Sometimes, classes haven't been written and instructors have to build & teach a class on the fly.
•Administration gets very excited about the amount of money spent on Xeroxes, yet mandated textbooks provided that are difficult to use, deal w irrelevant topics/projects, out of date information or from British culture. 
•Students do not have a grounding in the career field they are entering, and have unrealistic expectations.
•Office environment isn't conducive to creativity or quick changes. Re-models are very expensive results of poor choices.
•Faculty not given respect, adequate pay, office space, privacy.

review_title: Burning their people left and right
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Portland, OR
pros: I loved the connection with creative students and the chance to make a positive impact. The faculty and staff were willing to work hard and put themselves aside for the good of the student body. This used to be an institution that kept its unique integrity and kept the corporate demands at bay long enough to let employees enjoy their work.
cons: Ridiculously outdated sales and marketing techniques and technology. I mean seriously, a DOS-based sales management tool is embarrassing for a company selling high-tech educational programs to students at astronomical prices. As they look for ways to continue to boost profit, they get closer and closer to an unethical line in order to make the numbers. I used to be proud to say I worked here. I am sad to say that is no longer the case.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Being able to help students who have a real passion for creativity, get to work with pretty great people across all the different departments, ongoing training and great benefits (health, dental, vision, 401k, PTO)
cons: 401k is not matched; having to work weekends at least 2x per month, which used to be only half days but transitioning to full days soon without the ability to flex out for a whole day the following week. Manager micro manages constantly and always has a negative attitude about the numbers, even though the school tries to say "it's not a numbers game"

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: The only thing decent about this place was the co-workers in the admissions department.
cons:
-The location in San Francisco, is terrible! Anyone considering going to school here or work, please be aware of the location. It is not safe! They make you work until 8 at night twice a week and it's terrible! A lot of bums in this neighborhood. 
-The Director at the time, was horrible! He was a micro manager and there were rumor going around that he threw his keyboard at someone for not producing. 
-The work environment was very much like a high school. 
- When I started, I was ready to leave! I was lucky enough to get out of this place. 
- They make you do these horrible "interview" with these famlies for 90 minutes just to sell them on the school and getting their application from them. 
- Overall, I do not recommend this place to anyone. There are better schools to work at. 
-There is also no such thing as work/life balance at all! So if you have small children, please stay away from this place.

review_title: Horrible micromanagement hell .... sinking ship stay away at all costs
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Fairly good pay and good coworkers. Students are, for the most part, passionate and driven - it's great to help them.
cons: Micro management from people who have absolutely zero management skills.... pathetic! They literally and figuratively follow the president around to try and look good without regard to the whole team. Management often asks you what you think then turn around to use your opinions against you. This place is a joke and there is no action based resolutions just punishment and guilt trips about not hitting quotas and metrics that constantly make you feel like a terrible employee. The goal is always moving so you never feel accomplished. This is certainly the place you go to learn a lot really fast and move on. The change to a not for profit institution also creates an air of insecurity. While it is on a logical level a good move, it feels like a shady change to avoid recent legislation against for profit schools. Lastly, there are no places to relax and enjoy your lunch or spare time as a student or as an employee.

review_title: Incredibly high turnover, no integrity, very disorganized.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Cincinnati, OH
pros: It is common knowledge in the admissions department that this is a "good easy job" to have while you're looking for another one since they pay $40K per yr plus benefits. They tend to hire outgoing employees which made it a fun place to work briefly, but within weeks we all became fed up with the lying in order to enroll students, not to mention micromanagement like none of us had ever seen.
cons: Although the position title is Assistant Director of Admissions, this is not an admissions position or a leadership position in any way. It's a call center and there are about 25 "Assistant Directors." Cubicles, lists of phone numbers, endless metrics for how many phone calls/appointments you should have in a day/week/month. Even if you love sales, beware; employees with incredibly strong sales backgrounds were also disgusted with business practices. We witnessed consistent dishonesty and manipulation of low-income students. Management is out of touch, disrespectful, and doesn't care about the well-being of students.

review_title: Huge let down. Left a great career to be sold a pipe dream.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
Great, competitive salary. One of the highest I have seen out there in the private education industry. 
Free education to the employee after 6 months of full time employment, and then the benefits are extended to your spouse and children after 1 year of service.
cons: Schedules are not flexible, not great if you have a family (as your hours can run over, you will be required to work several late nights, weekends and events.) There's not a work-life balance present.  The company is currently under fire for a lawsuit and constant cuts are being made within the company to protect assets. They recently took away our 401k plan. They used to match, then cut their percentage, and then completely dismantled the program in order to "cut costs" and save money. 70% of the leads they give you don't turn into applications, and you're often left to fend for yourself to build a class. You're required to make a minimum of 100 calls per day.

review_title: Take the good with the bad.
job_title: Instructor in Seattle, WA
pros:
Student focused curriculum that when presented properly encourages critical thinking and growth. 
Department directors are doing their best to stay focused on the quality of education.
Some of the downsizing has actually refocused goals; combining some areas with Argosy University has created a more lively vibe in the halls.
The faculty and much of the staff have high levels of professionalism and integrity, even with  all of the chaos the past few years they still try to give the students a quality expereince.
cons: As others have mentioned, there have been significant shifts in corporate goals and profit. They send out quarterly reports stating how we've made the company money shortly after laying off staff and facutly. This is definitely a top-down management company with all of us at the bottom trying to do the best for the students with less and less support.

review_title: Encouraged to learn and do things independently.
job_title: Student Worker in San Antonio, TX
pros: Being able to complete tasks independently. Micromanaging was absent with him, he would give out tasks every month and would let you be in control of your own deadlines. He understands the needs of the students and is very reasonable with sick time. He was a great manager.
cons: Tasks were sometimes out of pay grade. The pay was horrible. It could be pretty stressful at times with dealing with management higher then him. The senior managers do not hire enough employees to manage daily operations properly. So you will have much more work then your pay reflects. They take advantage of the student workers.

review_title: A Cautionary Tale: How EDMC Ruined the Art Institutes
job_title: Full Time Faculty in Atlanta, GA
pros:
-Outstanding faculty
-Close knit campus
-Student-centered culture (faculty made this possible, not management)
-Many hard-working and sincere students
cons:
-Corporate management culture obsessed with the profits of shareholders over the needs of the students
-Obsession with quantity of students enrolled rather than the quality of students being recruited
-Deteriorating reputation in the industry (as a result of the above)  
-Overly aggressive, desperate acting Admissions departments 
-Incompetent or ego-driven leadership at many levels
-Poor retention (as a result of commonly recruiting students that lack resources, transportation or aptitude for college-level work)

review_title: The Art Institute of Pittsburgh Online Division - A mixed bag.
job_title: Admissions in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: This is a very fast growing division of Education Management Corporation.  There is tremendous potential for advancement.  EDMC is an extremely large corporation that owns three schools - The Art Institutes, Argosy University, and South University.  Each of these schools has an online division as well as numerous ground campuses.  The company is currently privately owned but is considering going public.
cons: High turnover. Unrealistic goals. No consideration of work/life balance. Poor leadership that shows little respect for employees.  Senior management is two-faced.  Overall, the workforce is very young and inexperienced.  Even lower level managers have little experience. If you have a family and value balance, management looks down upon you.  Employees are bullied to work overtime and Saturdays.  If you don't put in the extra hours, management considers you disloyal.

review_title: Great Company, awesome Art Students, not the nicest employees to work with
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Charleston, SC
pros: I love my job. Working with the students and helping them on a daily basis is what excites me! We always have something interesting going on at the school as we have programs in Culinary, Fashion, Design and Media.  I love the time off given through the benefits plan as well as the health insurance, life insurance, adoption benefits, 401K, disability,  and the opportunity to get your Maters within EDMC.
cons: I love everything about this job besides the people that work here as Staff/Faculty. Many people are negative and not happy about life in general. It makes it difficult to stay positive with such negative co-workers around you daily.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Pay was above average and I enjoyed working with the creative students and staff. The technology and curriculum were amazing for the students.  Great paid time off package for quality of life.
cons: Corporate has a cookie cutter approach that does not get adjusted at the local campus level. I was told that the quantity of calls over quality was their expectation. I had 3 Directors in less than 2 years. The schedule was changed all the time in admissions.  From my perspective, the right and left hand do not know what the other is doing, hence the announcement of a gradual campus shut down.

job_title: Student Accounting Supervisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The students and being around all of their creativity was great! When I was there the inter-departmental camaraderie was strong. It was a great opportunity to learn from each other, see how each department operated for the good of the school/ student, and work towards the same goals which were to help the student's success and graduate. The teachers are stellar at AIPX too!
cons: For profit schools became quite the target which caused mass downsizing and terminations. They were poorly handled and many great people were released from their positions. Too political, lost it's innovative spirit, and became a very rigid / corporate environment. Unrealistic job expectations followed each employee terminations.

job_title: Faculty in Santa Monica, CA
pros: Time off.  8 weeks in total over the course of the year.
cons:
No job security whatsoever.  This company is going through massive upheaval and hemorrhaging students as a result.  Enrollment is as low as its ever been and classes are getting cancelled constantly.  Full timers have priority and if their courses get dumped they will give them the classes to make sure they maintain their status.

Instructors are required to provide the school with their entire curriculum 'for review'.  They then give your teaching materials to the instructors that have been dropped into the course at the last minute having never taught the material in the past. 

If you are desperate enough to take a position here, be sure to keep looking for work as you will need to have a game plan in a few months.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Depending on what department you work in, the job can actually be fun. Working closely with the students is the best part. Benefits were great, even used to have bonuses (even though that's recently been shut down).
cons: They consistently cut positions and dump their workload onto other employees with no increase in salary. Raises were frozen for the last two years I worked there with talks of that continuing indefinitely to "provide students with an affordable tuition" even though they still increase tuition. It got to the point where if our department needed to order office supplies we were questioned as to how necessary it was...I'm sorry, but pens and post-its were necessities and catered lunches for Executive staff is not.

review_title: Not a healthy environment- stay away!!
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Seattle, WA
pros: Free classes & a good view. I really wish I could say more
cons:
-This is hands down he worst company I have ever worked for. I say company because they pretend to be a school, but in all reality this is a sales organization. No one is happy here. Turnover is INCREDIBLY high.

-The company is part of EDMC (Education Management Corporation) - do your research and you will see just how awful this company is. Several lawsuits/investigations against them due to recruiting practices. 

-Management- The absolute worst. They micromanage to the fullest and do it in a very bi-polar manner. It's a numbers game where the students do not matter and that's all they care about. I really don't know how they can even sleep at night knowing what they do.

-The people who stay here the longest have no career aspirations, self-confidence, and think this is how a normal job is supposed to be....especially the "managers". I've never been managed by such unintelligent people.

review_title: The students is what makes you want to stay.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
EDMC runs this place like a well oiled machine. This is a professional business so many aspects of the structure are implemented and presented in an organized matter. 
Great benefits and PTO
Great students with fresh minds 
Awesome people to work with
cons:
Everything is based on metrics: especially Admissions 
You start to feel guilty like you have sold your soul, the this gets to you. 
Staff and Faculty that have been with the company for a long time seem to use seniority to their advantage.
FREE Employee education is really "you pay first. They pay you back."
PTO doesn't matter since they really don't want you to take time off
You realize the students that graduate haven't really picked up any skills.
To start to realize they students aren't getting what they are paying for., the students start to question Admissions, Career Services, Student Services and a Financial Aid.

review_title: Worst teaching experience I've ever had.
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Helping students learn—even though I was not respected at all for my hard work.
cons:
• Absolutely horrible compensation (about $2000/ 11-week course after taxes for 11 weeks)
• Constant pressure to manage a massive amount of details for 80+ students.
• Management that either did not care about adjuncts, or was under pressure by management to work us to the bone. Probably both.
• Horrible ethical lapses with regard to recruiting. They did not care if recruits had proven ability to succeed. Admitted almost anyone with a pulse.
• Constant, discouraging feeling that I was some sort of educational janitor, beholden to the Goldman & Sachs Gods far off in their NYC temple. I understand that G&S has sold the whole circus. But I expect nothing different with new group in terms of what I experienced.
• Constant pressure to do well on quarterly reviews from your manager(s) and students. Then they pit you against your fellow instructors in terms of the outcome. I did OK, but it was demoralizing. And it accomplished nothing more than dash instructor motivation to help students learn.

review_title: Pay is not worth the stress
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Dallas, TX
pros: Great benefits, liked most of my coworkers, School itself is awesome.  Faculty and educational offerings are amazing.  Everyone other than Admissions department is happy to be there.  I love the idea of this job - but absolutely hated it by the time i left.
cons: Pay and hours were not at all what I was told when I was hired.  They seriously over-promised on advancement opportunities and raises.  Unrealistic sales goals.  Lots of catty women in the department.  Incompetent management.  Double standards.  People who the directors liked got preferential treatment, and if they didn't like you they made your life hell.  Poor use of time.  Meetings about meetings about meetings, and then several emails from different people about the content of the meetings.  Micromanagement.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Seattle, WA
pros: It used to be the money, but the financial incentives are no longer there due to recent legislation. During my time there, the admissions team was an amazing group of people, excluding those in management.
cons: The ADA is a salesperson, plain and simple. I was hired on believing that I was helping creative kids get a quality education in the commercial arts and culinary, but this was not the reality. 150+ calls per day off of lists of names that had already told AIS that they were no longer interested in speaking with the school was a minimum requirement. The goals set by EDMC were outrageous considering the amount of money that went into the facilities and educators. No matter how well you felt you did, it was never good enough for this company.

review_title: Education not priority, terrible place to work
job_title: Assistant Professor in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Online allows for a lot of flexibility in hours worked.
cons: Every year this job gets worse. Enrollment drops. They take something away from us, or give us more work. Management is too incompetent to ever make something better. There are more lawyers than teachers. They are more worried about getting sued than teaching people. Legal prevents even the most basic things from getting accomplished. It is a corporate monster that only operates only to make money and has no other values. No upward mobility in the job. No tenure. Advancement is title only just for show and does not include financial rewards.Flexible hours, but you will work every day. Hard to get actual time off.

job_title: Student Worker in Austin, TX
pros: As a tutor I was able to easily maintain the quality of my own school work while helping my peers when they came in for a visit. Tutors and other student worker areas have a work load that allow us to have time for our own work once we've finished our duties.
cons: Office hours are killer. On days when we have to sub because there is no student worker coverage we have no time at all for anything but office work and we are consistently pulled in several directions at once. There is also a tremendous amount of trust placed upon us when working the office given the type of information and situations we come in contact with.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Able to connect with wide variety of arts industry professionals in the area, supportive faculty, occasional breakthroughs with students.
cons: Administration ignores problem students (unprepared to potentially violent). Blames faculty for failing students, citing lack of engagement or exciting, fun material. Overcrowded classrooms without proper supplies. Lowest pay rate in the area, expected to work as a full time professor would while receiving part-time pay.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Discount on attending school within the EDMC system. Sometimes you get to wear jeans on Fridays. The environment from fellow ADAs is wonderful. Everyone works very hard.
cons: Working in admissions (sales) you are micro-managed, sometimes every 15-30 minutes with productivity. Nearly every time a student does not sign up for school you are questioned and scrutinized for what YOU did wrong. High pressure sales tactics to have students sign up, even if not in their real best interest.

review_title: Not Bad for starting in Sales but Very few stay for a reason
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Dallas, TX
pros:
They train you on how to be better at your craft, marketing and sales. 
The people are nice.
Our local management was there to help us succeeded.
It's a great College with great Professors, and world class education
cons:
The metrics start easy and get SO hard, it's seems like no matter how much money you bring in for them, it's just not enough. 
It's a HIGH Pressure Environment and your always on the edge of getting fired. 
Lot of people get fired. 
Lot of people left because they could make more money in sales else where. 
Corporate breathers fire down on you and your local managers without knowing what's going on locally.

review_title: One of the worst places to work,  in my entire working career.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions EDMC ONLINE HIGHER ED in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Not many! feel sorry for new hires at the Cotton Center location in Phoenix Arizona. Pros new hires continue to look for other employment, use what ever position you get at the Art Institutes of Pittsburgh Online for a pay-check,
cons: New hires  don't know what they are in for, they will find out soon enough. low morale, leadership uses bullying techniques. Managers especially those in  Finance and Admissions treat team members that are not the favorites like dirt! Plus there are those in leadership positions that don't know their jobs Directors and Managers. Plus they use their power like they are ruling over their own personal kingdom. If you are a person of color forget about ever being seriously considered for a leadership position! Beware EDMC stock is less that $2 a share that speaks volumes. Everyone who leaves on their own or are let go have a better quality of life because they are away from the negative and evil energy that permeates that environment!

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Benefit plans, Tuition Voucher, Pay, PTO
cons: Disloyal leadership, fearful atmosphere, deceit, favoritism, apathetic leadership, backstabbing atmosphere,  no performance feedback or reviews for new employees, negative feedback, zero training, bullying management, will fire anyone without performing an investigation or ever giving warnings, lawsuits throughout the company constantly, Allows some to break policies and fires others; can't find the consistency

review_title: Great company, working out the kinks.
job_title: Career Services in Seattle, WA
pros: Helping students achieve their dreams is an incredible reason to get up and go to work everyday. I have loved seeing the programs change and how our graduates are becoming more qualified and getting better jobs each quarter. It's wonderful to be a part of their success. Working hard to eliminate the kinks in the curriculum and help our students more and more every quarter.
cons: Constant change and alterations to information required. Poor reputation in the industry with some companies that is difficult to overcome with some graduates' quality of work.

review_title: Micromanaging group of profit-seeking managers make your experience miserable
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Houston, TX
pros: The pay is decent. The benefits and paid time off are good. The work is really simple. You do the same thing over and over again with little to no variation. Good opps for overtime pay.
cons: 40 Assisant Directors in the Houston branch, and in one calendar year, 30 quit or were fired. They micromanage you by the minute. If you cannot figure out how to break their system of profit-seeking enrollment methods, you will be miserable. I was fortunate to be very good at the work, so I was left alone. Others I worked with left every day emotionally broken down. The hours are terrible (late evenings, Saturdays). Again, 28 people quit or were fired out of the 40 ADAs at AIH. I know you may be desperate for work (like I was), but save yourself the headache and work elsewhere for a few months and wait for something better. People that had been there for more than a few years ended up in the hospital due to work-related stress.

review_title: Pass on ANY ADA position and value yourself!
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Meeting and talking with prospective students
cons: Know that you're "selling" students an education that is too expensive and not necessarily accredited.  It's a FOR-PROFIT "college" meaning that it's the admissions office job to recruit and keep up with numbers instead of really helping the students and their families throughout the admissions process.  Expect to spend all day on the phone chasing down 'leads' (calling a list of potential students who showed interest either by just clicking a site or calling a 'warm call' line).

review_title: Do NOT work for this company!!!!
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Atlanta, GA
pros: I grew very close with my co-workers because you basically live there.
cons:
-Terrible hours. You work until 7 & 8 twice a week and 9-5 on Saturday. Often times you will only have Sunday off because several days are blocked off the calendar.
- it's all about the numbers. They do not care about the students! Several students would come in with food stamps and we still had to convince them why they should be in school, tearing at their heart strings and asking them to share their story with us.
- Unrealistic numbers. They continue to increase your numbers and make it nearly impossible for you to achieve your plans. To make matters worse, you are no longer compensated for your numbers and they froze annual raises until further notice. So you are asked to enroll students and get written up if you don't make your plan but then don't get compensated for all of your hard work. 
My advice???  DO NOT work for this company. Our entire team was miserable and you have NO work/life balance.

review_title: Schaumburg Admissions dept struggling due to leadership
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Schaumburg, IL
pros: High salary with no experience in academic recruiting needed; overall good opportunity for the students served; great benefits including 401k match and tuition assistance
cons: Management at this campus manages the team through intimidation when they see fit - most of the admissions staff work hard but fear for their jobs or frivolous write ups in their "permanent file." They are highly knowledgeable and skilled in admissions, but refuses to admit their own shortcomings and are intimidated by employees with opinions, retaliating by threatening and/or pushing ADAs out through biased performance reviews/certifications.  This reputation is known by various departments and has resulted in high turnover in the department and an overall lack of responsiveness by faculty/staff to Admissions initiatives.  Staggered work schedule (9-6/8-11) makes it somewhat difficult to find work/life balance if you have an otherwise busy life/commitments.  College is struggling to meet enrollment goals at most campuses so future outlook doesn't look too good.

review_title: Watch your back if you work there!!
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in San Antonio, TX
pros: Some amazing professors.  Small classrooms for students.  Great updated equipment for students.  Programs are very specialized and if it is the right fit could be great for the student.
cons: for profit school that is having all kinds of issues internally.  Restructuring recently and closing of many schools has made things not so great for employees or many students.  Who knows if even the good schools will stay open.  Management does not seem to care about employees no matter how good performance is.  There are a lot of cliques and unprofessional relationships in the office.  If you decide not to join it could cost you your job.

review_title: I recruit, interview, and enroll students
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The company puts a lot of effort into developing and coaching employees. I have learned a lot about leadership skills and have been able to develop quite a bit as a professional.
cons: Your performance ratings are based upon factors that can be out of our control. This can be discouraging at times, as it can be with any job. Sometimes it can feel like a sales atmosphere, but it is not supposed to, Our objective is to service students, and if we don't have students to service, we find ourselves in a rut.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Seattle, WA
pros:
Get to work with a lot of creative, fun people.
Get to help people with education
cons: I was at AIS for 15 months, and in that time we had three school presidents, two HR directors (the second one quit right after I left), and all leadership in my department turned over.  Among the workers in my dept, there was 100% turnover in that time.  We also received many mixed messages about how to do the admissions role.  On one hand, we were told that it's "the right student in the right program at the right time."  On the other hand, we were also told to get them in for an interview "and reel them in."  Also, the 2nd HR manager told me that this wasn't a job to have if you liked work/life balance.

job_title: Full Time Instructor in San Antonio, TX
pros: One of the easiest jobs I have ever had in my life. Although this was something between a con and a pro. They no longer allowed me to teach and required me to use a strange math program where I essentially became a tutor or baby sitter. it became very unfulfilling  and boring. The only pro i can think of was my co workers and students were very interesting and laid back.
cons:
Management was ridiculous. Place was run by people with no real background in the field I was teaching in. I was a mathematics instructor, with a supervisor that had a degree in acting and communications....

Benefits package is shrinking. We started with a decent retirement and salary, then suddenly people got laid off and our retirement contributions were no longer matched by the company. Restructuring and lay offs seemed rampant through out the company as a whole. 

They also started closing various schools around the country.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in San Diego, CA
pros: Decent pay, contact hours condensed into one day a week made it workable with other contract projects. Students willing to learn made the classroom atmosphere pleasant.
cons: No promise of class assignments for adjunct from quarter to quarter. Impossible to include as a steady source of employment--in one of the most expensive cities in the US to live. Staff comes and goes, so little real direction or guidance. They are working to set higher standards, but they are trying to go from zero to 100 in two quarters, in efforts to maintain their certification. No real regard for instructor backgrounds or degrees that can lead to other areas of instruction assignments.

review_title: Fulfilling and rewarding on a day to day basis.
job_title: Graphic Design Instructor in Austin, TX
pros: The freedom to design your own curriculum; the daily interaction with the students; amazing co-workers; flexible schedule; 4 weeks of a year.
cons: School is no longer academically driven, but profit driven; quality of incoming students has dropped in an effort to raise enrollment; lack of support on the corporate level; lack of job security.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Chicago, IL
pros: Working for AI in the beginning wasn't so bad but when the market for student declined the culture got worse by the day. Even though it is a for-profit education school, the culture is pretty much sales and you will be a tougher individual.
cons: Working for AI wasn't so bad in the beginning of my career, but when the company started declining in profit they turned into something else. They started giving on realistic expectations and made the work environment very difficult. While I was there about 20 people quit or found a new job in a very such period. I will not recommend this company to anyone

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Great work environment in terms of the team you are around. Good pay, but benefits are terrible. You can learn a lot about customer service and grow really thick skin.
cons: The hours are not good at all. A lot of cold calling. Bad morals and ethics. It feels like a telemarketing job at times. If you do not mind persuading kids and adults into a "water-downed" degree you will do fine.

job_title: Academic Coordinator Graphic in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The campus has great people to work with. The students are focused and love what they are learning. This is the second Art Institute campus I have worked at and the kind of people who work at both are consistently committed to the creative community at the college.
cons: The Salt Lake campus was one that EDMC decided to teach out as they reduce the number of campuses around the country. It is too bad as the team is very committed to excellence.

review_title: Chaos, companies going through a big transition from for-profit to nonprofit! No job security!!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Austin, TX
pros: There aren't a lot of positive things to say about the company. One good aspect  is helping students getting through to graduation. When get to help students overcome the deficiencies of the school programs.
cons: No consistency, no 401(k) benefits, no regular annual raises, leadership turns over every year. Bureaucracy stops you from assisting your students, resources on campus are not sufficient and hinder your performance. You work about two or three weekends out of the month, with no overtime, you have to shave hours during the week. Constant fear of whether or not the school will stay open is very stressful. Likelihood of the company staying open is grim. Constant micromanagement, unrealistic goals, turnover rate extremely high in all departments.

job_title: Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working with the students was absolutely wonderful. It was exciting to see the results of their creativity at the quarterly portfolio show. And while on campus, you can feel their energy. My job was particularly exciting as I was able to effect real change on how the campus operated.
cons: The tuition cost is very high. That can be demotivating to many of the students. Plus, the jobs that are offered to them, as part of the obligation of the school at the time of graduation, are low wage. I understand that they are just beginning their new career, but there is no way that they will be able to pay off their student loans. It just creates a negative environment in some ways.

job_title: Student Employment Advisor in Brookline, MA
pros:
Great staff, knowledgeable faculty and enthusiastic students. A great working environment that provides top notch training with state of the art equipment. 

Working in Career Services in particular, these are a great bunch of people.
cons:
Some entrenched do-nothings and lay abouts exist in this organization. It can be difficult working with the parent company, EDMC, who holds the purse strings.  There is a disconnect between the corporate side of things in Pittsburgh and the scholastic local college culture.

Over zealous admissions expectations can sometimes lead the school in to trouble; budgetary wise and with regards to student entrance standards.

review_title: Not the job I thought going in... Targets students who cannot afford school.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Atlanta, GA
pros: I love love love most of my co workers.... There are some great people here... but most of them have gotten let go.
cons: The management isn't concerned with employee moral or retention. I came in about 7 months ago and since then over ten people have left or been let go. It's sales, but we target lower income students here who are very often unable to stay in school due to financial issues. The retention rate is terrible and it is not a good work place. Also they micromanage like no other!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Arlington, VA
pros: You get to work with students and faculty in an academic setting. The people who work here are almost always very nice and they are people-people. The facility at AiW is OK, not the latest and greatest, but not falling apart either. Does not seem to be into scamming students into attending. Great faculty work here, but many have unfortunately been let go or have moved on...
cons: The IT and WiFi in building could be better. The turn-over is crazy high. Corporate dictates a lot of what happens at the campus. They don't spend much on developing the faculty/staff or invest in newer technology / furniture in building.

job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Seattle, WA
pros: Coworkers truly do care about student success; departments work diligently to resolve problems that they can handle without the corporate offices.  The work stays at work, it does not follow you home.  All of the employees at the campus level want to see students succeed.
cons: Senior management and the corporate offices are so far removed from interaction with students that their policies and processes serve to only infuriate and push student to withdraw.  Poor benefits (removed 401k matching six months after hire), and poor pay.  In all departments besides Admissions, the corporate offices will reduce your department to below what is necessary in order to adequately meet the needs of the students.  We have one registrar, no accountants, and a drastically reduced faculty and financial aid department.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Santa Monica, CA
pros: the management is encouraging and do recognize good results and hard work.  working with kids and having the feeling that you're helping them with their future is pretty fun and fulfilling.  good benefits and working in a somewhat artistic setting.
cons: scheduling can be inconvenient for a good work-life balance.  required to work a later shift at least two times a week.  required to work some saturdays and holidays.  a lot of turnover as the department is quite large itself.  there also seems to be a lot of competitive personalities, which is positive and negative.

review_title: micromanaged, overworked admissions staff encouraged to do whatever it takes to bring in new students.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Brookline, MA
pros: easy way to get exposure in a university setting for someone looking to get into this field -- they're always hiring
cons: cold calling, endless metrics (how many calls, interviews, applications per week, day, hour), culture of negative reinforcement, high stress, long hours.

review_title: A terrible place to work. They only care about numbers not students or employees. Lots of turn over.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Phoenix, AZ
pros: You can get a free education here
cons: The cooperate culture in negative. The company is in serious financial trouble and there are few new leads. Lots of pressure and micromanagement to sell, sell, sell without any thought of the student.  Management has little concern for the well being of it's employees. You feel as though you could be let go any day and many of us are walked out almost on a daily basis.

review_title: National Organization with serious conflict of interest between educational goals and corporate greed
job_title: Faculty in Kansas City, KS
pros: Great earnest students who want to learn.
cons: This is probably the best of the for-profit college groups, the most ethical, the most together organizationally, but that still leaves a lot to be desired.   The interest of the students is always secondary in managements' eyes to the profit margin.   So Faculty salaries, equipment, and other things necessary to achieve the educational goals are often not given the fiscal support required.  That said there are lots of great faculty and some great program Chairs who are dedicated professionals, trying to do right by the students.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in York, PA
pros: Good health benefits and PTO . Relationships with students and families are rewarding. Love my coworkers
cons: Unrealistic goals and expectations. Revolving door in the admissions department. Working there is like living on death row...if you are not reaching your unrealistic goals you will be fired...every day you go to work you wonder if that is the day you will be let go. This position is sales! Don't be fooled! If you think you are going into this position to counsel students then you have been deceived.  There is not enough time in the day to do what is expected of you. I was there for 4 years when I finally had a nervous breakdown, ended up on meds for stress and anxiety. I never had panic attacks until I endured the stress from this job. My advice.......don't even consider this position!!!

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Houston, TX
pros: Besides a decent salary, there are no pros.
cons: You are only as good as your last week of production. Management creates a facade that they care about you in the beginning, but that's just to get you to work harder. You will be fired in a heartbeat if you are not producing every single week. The schedule is not good if you have a family and only got worse over the year I worked there, as the number of saturdays we were required to work each month increased. You are pressured to enroll students in to programs they clearly cannot afford, with an unclear return on their investment. I was a very good Assistant Director of Admissions that was consistently ranked in the top 10, but it is not worth it. The job is a dead end.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Brookline, MA
pros: Helped some students change their life through education.
cons: Management constantly threatened to fire us if we didn't make our goals- 50 calls a day (this has doubled since I left), 12 appointment sets a week, 8 interviews a week, 4 applications taken each week, and two personally developed referrals a week. With the economy being so tough and the cost of the for profit school so high ($120K+ for a Bachelor of Science), these numbers are extremely tough... Especially with the sheer number of colleges in Boston. Management also creates conflict through the cutthroat competition amongst reps.

job_title: Admissions in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Thorough training, good salary, nice to engage with students about their passions and make a difference. great coworkers that make the day fun & enjoyable.
cons: Unstable management at corporate level. lack of communication - things change quickly but are not shared. management leaves & no one mentions it or even when/why. tuition is too expensive for the quality therefor huge drop out rate. lack of encouragement in the office. was told to 'put your paycheck on it' when asked to estimate what could be delivered. seems very inapproriate to say that & came across as threatening / bullying. was told would be working an occassional saturday but worked VERY often. this was not accurately stated.

review_title: Good place to work as a student worker
job_title: Peer Tutor in Orlando, FL
pros: Flexible hours, workload is average, but you still have time to work on personal assignments. There was a lot of trust in the area I worked on, so, most of the time I was unsupervised.
cons:
Pay is a little bit low for what I was doing.
Also, since you are working with other student workers, some of them are immature, and they do not understand they are in a real job, instead of just, doing whatever they want.

review_title: Reeled in by Job Security, Work-Life Balance, and Opportunity for Growth... NOT POSSIBLE!!!
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Mississauga, ON
pros: Compensation.  Learning how to train yourself and run your own "business".  Working with the interesting students.  Meeting great colleagues.
cons: Toxic Work Environment due to management,  Very Numbers Driven,  Employee Retention is very low.  Students are just a number.  If you don't reach your goals, you're out of a job.  No opportunity for growth within the same location.  POOR WORK LIFE BALANCE.

review_title: Online Adjunct Faculty of Graphic Design
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Santa Ana, CA
pros:
You definitely have a lot of flexibility as to when you want to work within a 24hr time frame, but you do have to login just about every day or you'll fall behind in your classes, very quickly.

Manager was decent and helpful when I ran into unknowns.
cons: Pay is atrocious. Worst adjunct compensation I've ever seen. Fringe benefits were offered at one point but once the enrollment started to go down all benefits were removed.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: If you want to be in corporate sales, this is a great place to start. Daylight shifts, no work on Sunday. If you make your numbers it's a guaranteed pay check.
cons: If your in Admissions your in sales. There are hourly, daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly, and annually goals you have to hit.  LOT OF PRESSURE. Lot of people don't make it. I prayed and was blessed; wouldn't have made it without Jesus.  You are expected to make 80 to 100 calls a day and bring aprox 1.2M annually but you only get $45k in return.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Chicago, IL
pros: This was a good place to gain some valuable teaching experience. Other faculty members are a joy to work with, and the academic directors were always very supportive.
cons: No benefits: no insurance, no 401(k) matching (they took this away from us), no paid time off (not even for jury duty). No job security. Pay freezes were a regular occurrence. Ridiculous amount of paperwork and quarterly training modules (for which we were not compensated) Faculty members often find out the week before the new academic term that their course would not be running or that they have been laid off. Zero opportunity for advancement.

job_title: Career Services Advisor in Mississauga, ON
pros: Ability to work autonomously, enjoyed planning events such as career fairs and portfolio shows, liked working with creative students and employers in the creative industries.
cons: Our bonuses were taken away, pay was adjusted but not fairly for those who continuously met top goals, very numbers oriented, which was fine for me but others with more of a counseling background it wasn't as good of an experience.

review_title: Not an educational institution, a people factory.
job_title: Fulltime Instructor in Arlington, VA
pros: Hours were good.  At first, the culture was great and collaborative.  Many of my peers were interested in making a difference in students lives.
cons: After the parent company (EDMC) was bought by Goldman Sachs, the culture has degraded.  The focus is now on turning a profit.
