Many corporate decisions from the top do not benefit the educational process. Classroom curriculum is often directed from management and people in completely unrelated fields.  Academic directors (who used to be qualified to teach the classes they managed) were let go and consolidated into various "branch management" type positions by people who have no idea what the course objectives are, let alone what a student's goals should be.  I could go on.

review_title: Culture of fear and more of a sales job
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Fort Worth, TX
pros: It is fulfilling to work with students that are passionate about art.
cons: It's more of a sales job bc you have to recruit a certain amount of students to meet your goals. Calling students from high schools etc. No where to move up in your position. They bombard you with a ton of training and make you memorize a presentation and think that's the fail safe method to get a student to attend. Management lacks organization.

job_title: Adjunct Pastry and Baking Instructor in Milwaukee, WI
pros:
Collaborating with other instructors
Teaching new cooks. 
Pay was good but they will try to find ways to not pay you for certain hours.
cons:
Everything about the corporate parent company. 
Shady recruitment procedures. 
After teaching my first semester of classes and planned on teaching the next semester I was informed two weeks before my class was scheduled to begin that they had canceled my class and I would not have a class. Poor planning and projection. 
The branch is not surprisingly slated to close when the current students have finished.

job_title: Part-Time Faculty in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: The only good thing I can think of is that classes are fairly small compared to community colleges.  There are a few good students in each class.
cons:
- I've seen a lot of employees quit this year with no prior notice (dean, directors) - not a good sign.
- This is a for-profit college, which means they're trying to make as much money as they can and pay you as little as possible.  The salary is way below community colleges'.
- Students are generally not motivated.
- If you need the management to do paperwork for you - good luck.  
- HR is incompetent.

review_title: A great opportunity... if you could feel good about yourself and what you're "offering" (pushing) to students
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Many great colleagues 
Ability to earn a great jump in salary, based on students (points) you enrolled during the previous year
cons:
Hard sell (get the student to start and attend classes, then it doesn't matter what happens)
Graduation rate was highly skewed--and used as a selling point, though not really explained truthfully

review_title: It's a GREAT Start!! Move on after 2 years
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Brookline, MA
pros:
Great people to work with and Directors know what they are doing when it comes to one to ones.
Hours are good and Directors will understand family life and time off if need be.
When you work with the best fit students...it makes this Job rewarding!!!
cons:
Although, Management is Wonderful personally...they are NOT CONSISTENT!! Let your staff do their work!!!!! 
Students you'll call are not really into college, there is a 5% student who know they want this school, 45% who know somewhat, but 50% who do not have a clue what they want. It's frustrating!

review_title: Example of a Large Nationwide  Multi-Campus For Profit College Looks Like
job_title: Instructor in Lenexa, KS
pros: Work with a staff that is second to none. Great group of people who make working for a faceless corporate entity a pleasurable experience. Couldn't ask to work with a group of stronger, more talented, more dedicated individuals.
cons: Working for a faceless corporate entity. There is not a  lot of direct intervention from corporate but when there is, it is  usually deployed as a surprise, without any consultation or input from local campuses and in a manner which shuts down any discussion of other options.

review_title: Bad business, bad attitudes, bad management, and bad education
job_title: Faculty in Boston, MA
pros: My students were really nice people. It was a great location with easy access to Boston.
cons: Low salaries, poor faculty culture, managers and department chairs who don't care about the quality of education or their staff. The business is a numbers game where the faculty are continually asked to lower their expectations in order to retain students who lack the basics of a Jr High education.

job_title: in Seattle, WA
pros: Equipment availability for projects is alright, along with an easy atmosphere to encourage learning, experienced teachers that actually do care if you make it
cons: Management is states away and doesn't really seem to care about students or faculty.  Internet servers are off site and therefore internet access, that is critical, is spotty and slow.  Sometime 'new' equipment isn't really an upgrade.

job_title: Admissions in Austin, TX
pros: Students are fun and inspiring
cons:
Hard to sleep at night knowing that you’re getting people to spend more than the education is worth to most likely drop out or not find a job in their industry if they make it to graduation with 60 grand + in debt. 

Admissions Management. Literally the worst bosses I’ve ever had or will have ever again. Zero communication. Passive aggressive. 

All of this makes for a terrible culture at work. I honestly hope the Art Institute of Austin closes so that no more students end up worse off than they were and any more employees end up hating life and constantly worrying about losing their job.

job_title: Teachers Aide in North Hollywood, CA
pros: As a student worker I not only was able to earn a paycheck to help with my bills but I was able to learn from the classes I assisted in. I learned rom a different perspective than just being the student. I also had the opportunity to build a good rapport with my teachers, which has been good for me after I graduated.
cons: Logging my hours through Kronos was a major headache, but other than that my experience was a positive one.

job_title: Front Office Manager (Receptionist) in Washington, DC
pros: I worked as the evening front office manager on a part-time basis and found it to be a great way to make some money while finishing up school. I was really only there to answer the phones and keep an eye on the front door, so there was a lot of downtime to be had and not much oversight which I found to be a good thing. I heard some buzz about thing being more difficult 'upstairs' but I was content to hang out in the lobby directing calls and walk-ins.
cons: Working for a For-Profit institution didn't feel too great, but the job itself was pretty solid.

review_title: Strong Faculty, Weak Dean, Terrible HR
job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Broomfield, CO
pros:
Autonomy. 
They let you teach.  
Academic Director's are good people who care about what they do.
Scheduling accomodates our needs.
Most of the faculty is very competent.
Good health insurance.
They previously had tuition reimbursement for further education.
Competent security.
Enthusiastic students.
cons:
Stinky bathrooms. Run down building.
Poor leadership from management above academic directors. Cronyism.
Admissions will sign anyone. I don't mean that in a good way.
Marketing slogans plastered all over the walls, even in classrooms. Not professional.
IT and computers lacking due to inadequate staffing.
Some of the textbooks imposed on the instructors by corporate are inadequate or fail to teach the subject.
Very little support from parent corporation. 
Housing overpriced and poorly run.

review_title: Film tutor for Sacramento campus, the experience was awesome, but the frequency of tutees was very low.
job_title: Student Tutor in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Very friendly management and the job itself was enjoyable. 
The pay itself was cool ($20/session).
The environment made my job easy (easy access to computers and quiet areas).
cons:
I was paid per tutoring session, which was very infrequent. 
Advertising of the tutoring program was up to each individual tutor but I didn't have much time to do that as I was a student there as well.

review_title: FA Officer- Good People not such a great company
job_title: Financial Aid Officer in San Diego, CA
pros: Everyone I worked with was amazing, hard workers and just good people who I built lasting relationships with. The healthcare and vision benefits were also pretty decent.
cons: A lot of continuous cutbacks for years. Removed the option for any overtime while increasing workloads due to hiring freezes and changes in management. Overall I believe the company is in a lot of trouble and there is not longevity.

review_title: You get out of it what you put into it
job_title: Time Management Tutor in Portland, OR
pros: Going to school at AI is great for getting an education on the equipment and for making business connections.
cons: I saw a lot of fellow classmates graduate saying "I don't feel like I really learned anything." We took several of the same classes, and I felt like I learned a lot, but I supplemented my AI education with outside learning from mentors and internships. Having an open education is good for those who have their own self-discipline and hard for anyone who thinks they're magically going to leave with all the skills they need.

job_title: High School Representative in Miami, FL
pros: Easy job if you are comfortable with public speaking.  Good team culture.  Stipends for vehicle, insurance, phone and internet.  Ton of time off in the Summer.
cons: No room for growth.  Company is doing bad because of unsustainable hyper-growth - a misstep by upper management - and employees are suffering for it while management continues to take bonuses.

job_title: in Brookline, MA
pros: Most of the people who work there are compassionate, caring, and work tirelessly to help students succeed in and out of the classroom. The talent pool of the professors is amazing to pass along to students as well.
cons:
It feels like a school, it runs like a school, but it's managed by a big corporation that puts business demands on an educational establishment.

There has been a culture of negativity being contagious and employees often joke when the next layoffs are going to happen.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The only pros were the pay and a handful of individuals I worked with, who got me through each day working there.
cons: The management was unsupportive, with the male managers making females uncomfortable. The training was minimal and weekly meetings left me leaving wondering how my manager got their job. The whole company ran unethically and tried recruiting students to the school under wrong standards. They pushed getting military individuals because they could make more money off of them, and once tried getting my colleague to recruit a homeless guy. I felt uncomfortable the entire time I worked there in every aspect.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Dulles, VA
pros: All of the professor were very professional and cared about their students.  The advisers are great and really try to work with your schedule when giving you classes to teach.  Small class size (max 25 students).
cons: Very low enrollment so classes I had planned/prepared to teach were cancelled one week before class started.  Because most professors are adjuncts you really don't interact with them.  There are not very many groups/organizations for students.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Passionate, motivated students make it a very rewarding place to work (I was in Admissions).  Very diverse student body, and extremely satisfying to watch the students grow and launch into the careers you've helped them achieve.
cons: Upper Management has made some bad choices in the past (and some of those choices are with regard to who has been in Upper Management).  Some of their "strategic" decisions made little sense, e.g., deciding to open and then to close various campuses.

review_title: For profit school owned by a big corporation; good, talented local people controlled by big level execs.
job_title: Full Time Faculty in Atlanta, GA
pros: My fellow teachers were, for the most part, talented and knowledgeable and really sincere about wanting to help students succeed, as were the Department Chairs and Dean. The support staff were helpful and knowledgeable. While they didn't have very high admissions standards for students, MOST students were dedicated and interested, really wanted to be there, and wanted to work hard. The facilities were OK but not as good as our competitors.
cons: Google "Art Institutes" to see negative. Very low admissions standards. Some students should not have graduated high school. A few teachers had never worked in the field in which they were teaching, or simply couldn't draw their way out of a bag. We were also dictated to by the owner corporation re: textbooks and curriculum changes, with very little say-so in what we thought the students needed. No raises for several years, followed by ridiculously large massive layoffs that were not thought through. Lots of VERY highly qualified faculty were let go and some of the bad ones stayed just because they'd been there longer. The good, dedicated students will be the ones most hurt by the layoffs.(Well, of course, other than the teachers who are now out of jobs...)

review_title: Greed and incompetent senior administrators wrecked this school
job_title: Department Chair in Boston, MA
pros: The faculty and (former) department chairs were unbelievably committed to students. NONE of the department chairs are currently employed. They took out one of the most influential to begin their takedown that lasted months and destroyed careers and harmed good families.
cons: This Charles Schwab owned for-profit college has gone WWAAAYY downhill due to poor management on the part of David Warren, incompetence of Jane Souza and greed on the part of the corporate office and Schwab.

review_title: Great faculty, good local support, for-profit focus at the corporste level.
job_title: Instructor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great focused programs and faculty.  Good facilities and on campus support.
cons: It's owned and operated by Education Management Corporation, which is owned by Goldman Sachs.  The main focus is ultimately profit through federal student loans.   There is pressure to get and keep any student who can get student aid regardless of the ability to succeed.   To save on costs, the Art Institutes laid off half it's full time faculty and replaced them with part time adjuncts.

review_title: Amazing experience to launch a career (at a small price)
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Houston, TX
pros: You will learn a ton in this job -- recruiting, interviewing, reaching goals, teamwork/leadership, problem solving, sales, relationship building, adaptability, time management... The Houston location has a beautiful school, successful programs and wonderful faculty. There is work-life balance in the sense that when you go home, you don't take your work with you. However, when you are in the office, you really need to know how to manage your time and work very hard. I don't think I would have the career I have today if it weren't for my time here.
cons: Proprietary school systems like the Art Institutes often receive bad press. Some of it is rightfully earned, and some not. Still, it is a big hit to employees' morale to hear negative things about your employer and the type of work you are doing. It is ALL about hitting your numbers (getting a certain number of students each start date) which means you sometimes have students sign up who probably shouldn't. In other words, unlike other respectable institutions of higher education, it's not about finding the best and most qualified student; it's about finding any student you can to sign on the dotted line and fork over a non-refundable $50 applicant fee. Of course, there are plenty of Admissions representatives who do their job well... and right... and only sign up students in good conscious. Doing it that way, however, takes much longer to hit your goals than just letting any old Joe Schmuck in the door. There were definitely Admissions reps who would persuade a student to sign up who they KNEW couldn't afford the tuition and/or wouldn't excel, but they did it anyway to hit their goals. It just made you feel icky sometimes.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Generally a good rapport among the employees and even your direct chair. Benefits were decent. Salaries can be decent for full-time but they are capped so work may pile on but your salary does not.  The teachers that work there really care, well most, about teaching their industry properly.
cons: Since they are now requiring a Masters for teachers, beware the some may not have the industry experience that one without a masters will have and  is FAR more valuable than one who just graduated with a BA/BS and then got Masters and straight to teaching or barely worked.  A fashion major in the past did not require a Masters as you went t o work and there were only 1-2 programs in the country. PT pay is not worth it if you live far.  Turn over rate is high because the type of student brought in was always a low quality student who did not want to work or expected things on a platter but if you know the industry it doesn't work that way and the upper management only cares about retaining the students so it is discussed at every meeting with instructors. There is high pressure to help students pass and some just should not be there. The school would be far more credible if it brought more  quality students.

review_title: It has been enjoyable at times but can be stressful depending on time of year and what is happening.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great co-workers, dependable management team in place currently, flexibility of schedule
cons: Atmosphere, lack of wanting to make right changes, constant changes, inability to be flexible with weekly schedules and Saturday schedules. It is too difficult to make necessary changes with so many different levels to go through.

review_title: Never a dull moment in the tutoring center
job_title: Student Tutor in Houston, TX
pros: Work scheduling flexible around class times. Diverse student body and majors allows you to network with your fellow peers you're tutoring. Each hour of each day brings a different tutoring challenge.
cons: Short handed on tutors of varied expertise. The bulk of students ask for last minute help to do an entire project from the beginning but is due in a few hours from when they walk in. Usually happened during midterms and finals. Volume of students seeking tutoring around these times often meant I was on my feet and talking nonstop for 4 hours straight.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in San Francisco, CA
pros: The base salary and benefits are great
cons: You are scamming people into paying for classes they cannot afford, including pushing them into taking out massive amounts of student loans.  At this school location, the Senior Director of Admissions and the Director of Admissions are the most unethical, unprofessional and uneducated people I have EVER worked for.  They are honestly horrible people. When you work in the Admissions department at this school, you are asked to do all kinds of unethical things to get students to pay for classes, including: lying to them, forging signatures, writing essays for them, etc.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Decent Salary to start, fun coworkers, decent hours and ability to request time off.
cons: Incompetent Senior Management, direct managers give little to no feed back and only worry about themselves professionally, payment scale/compensation scale is in a state of unknown change due to new government regulations, school will be losing a great deal of funding soon from the government due to high debt ratios that students incur.

review_title: Great colleagues but not a fan of for-profit education
job_title: Department Director in Nashville, TN
pros: The faculty are talented and care about the students.
cons: I liked my colleagues but the parent company expects too much of the employees without fair compensation.  This is a for-profit institution and they charge way too much for tuition from the students.  I think the facilities and equipment they offer the students is very good but it doesn't make up for the debt that the students incurre.  That was hard for me to live with.

review_title: Fulfilling work educating students and excellent co-workers, but poor pay, no benefits, and no chance of advancement.
job_title: Instructor in Tampa, FL
pros: Fulfilling and satisfying work helping students achieve their career goals.  Dedicated co-workers and a collegial and professional work environment.  Truly dedicated to providing students an excellent education.  Part time and adjunct employees eligible to participate in 401(k) program with company match and immediate vesting.
cons: Poor pay considering hours worked and need for a master's degree.  Only paid for contact hours - actual classroom time - and not for planning, preparation, grading, etc.  Little to no opportunity to become full time, almost entire teaching staff is adjunct.  Hours limited to 28 or less to avoid ACA requirements.  Other than 401(k) eligibility, no other benefits at all.  If you are sick and need to miss a class your pay is docked.  Company performance is down, and there have been several rounds of layoffs, although these did not affect teaching positions, however almost all support personnel are now gone.  No job security at all, and no knowledge  of how many (or indeed if any at all) classes you may be teaching from quarter to quarter.  The Tampa campus has suffered from a leadership vacuum, with more than 12 campus presidents over the past six years.  Parent company (EDMC) is under extreme scrutiny (along with other large for-profit private colleges) from department of justice and is facing a multi-billion dollar government lawsuit for defrauding on student loans.  Student population is dropping, and campus is contracting, resulting in fewer teaching opportunities in the future.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rosslyn, VA
pros: The best part about teaching is that I may be playing a little part in hopefully shaping a better future. Teaching, in general, is a gratifying job, and I am grateful for the experience.
cons: The organization is going through some tough times financially. A lot of turnover in the leadership and my manager changed three times while I was working there. I enjoyed working there, but the quality of work or skills from students are not great. The reason probably is because they accept all students that apply to the school instead of only taking the best students out there.

review_title: Not a career - soon it will not even be a business
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Novi, MI
pros:
The pay per hour is very high as it is on a contact hour basis. Faculty development sessions are paid as well as most out-of-class events if you help out with them in any way. No micro-management and you are essentially free to teach your classes how you want them to be taught.

Back when the adjuncts were allowed to teach three classes per quarter, the money was decent as long as you had other work.

The main facilities and equipment that we used were high quality, though they appeared to be more of a recruiting tactic than meant to be used in a practical sense.
cons:
Fear for the future is very high right now with all of the school closings as well as lay-offs for some of the employees in the campuses that are staying open. As an adjunct the number of classes you get varies, making it hard to depend on income. Also, time in between quarters can be brutal on budgets; a total of eight weeks (2 months) every year you will be out of work completely. Advancement is very difficult and I don't see the school leaning toward favorable measures for the future.

Also I get a lot of complaints from my students about the administrative side of the school. Sometimes they get charged more than they were promised and it leads to negative experiences. Several of my best students have left for this reason.

Speaking of students - the good ones made it a good experience.  The bad ones far outnumber them.  Most of them cannot be trusted or bothered to show up on time or do basic things like turn in assignments.  I don't believe these problems are exclusive to AI but the students are not really expected to be adults in any professional sense.  I had a number of students who would routinely outright fail or scrape by, but they were always enrolled in the next class.  I don't think the school does them any favors by just letting them come back no matter how poor of a student they are.

The attendance policy has changed in a terrible way and recently we were told we need to personally call every student who is absent every time they were absent as well as report our responses to senior management. In addition to this, we were told we need to serve at least one office hour every week unpaid. If I ever had a student show up for office hours, they would have been the first...this requirement was silly for adjuncts.

During my final year at AI, everyone seemed to be just waiting for the next batch of bad news.  While I received moderate raises after my first two annual reviews, I received no raise for the third.  This was despite massive improvements in my evaluations from both my students and my superiors. To top it all off, once the new healthcare laws kicked in, they cut back the number of classes I could teach so that I wouldn't qualify for any benefits.  This turned what was possibly a decent adjunct position into a below average job.  

Of course I looked for other work, and when I finally found a decent position outside of AI, I notified the president of my campus (because my boss was laid off in a string of cuts).  I gave my notice (3 weeks) and while I was doing extra course preparation for my classes, which started the next day, I discovered that my classes were no longer available from my end.  After conferring with another instructor, I discovered they gave away my classes to other instructors and didn't even tell me.

Had I not been doing extra preparation, I would have shown up ready to teach only to find out I didn't have a job. I would have been better off if I didn't give them a notice at all - they only used it against me.

A lot of people are either jumping ship or getting laid off.  We have been prodded to provide possible candidates to take our old positions, but even if I knew that many people who met the credentials I likely would not burden them with this sinking ship unless it was their only option.

review_title: Would give tem zero stars if that was an option
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Seattle, WA
pros: Good instructors, great location and decent course offerings
cons:
Micromanagement...all day, every day
During the initial interviews you are told that this is not a " sales" job. It is about helping the students to achieve their goals and dreams. Nothing could be further from the truth. It is all about emotionally browbeating some poor high school senior, laid off and disgruntled Burger King employee or ex military with GI benefits and getting them to apply. High pressure and unethical sales tactics are employed and condoned daily. As cool as the job may seem, listen to your inner voice and run like hell.

review_title: Fine first job, fresh out of college.
job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Seattle, WA
pros: I was hired here right after college. Hiring process was very fast, 1st interview Wednesday, second Thursday and hired later that day. Waited 1 week for a background check then was made an official offer. Benefits are good, and after 1 year they make up to 6% match in retirement contributions. Great people!!
cons:
The corporate structure is in the process of centralizing as much as possible. No direct contact between campus employees and corporate employees, except through company portal. 

After working here a few months, found out that there is very little upward mobility, a co-worker had been in the same position for 10 years (whether by choice or lack of advancement was unapparent). This was definitely a bummer as I am a young motivated employee looking to make my name at a company that so monotonously disregards skill and hard work. 

There use to be a structure bonus and pay grade evaluation annually, but recent laws have come into effect that inhibit "in-scope" workers at proprietary (for-profit) colleges. These changes removed incentives and bonuses from the Admission and Financial Aid departments as it was seen as incentive to use illegal recruiting techniques and cutting corners in financial aid process... Basically whether you are great or lousy at your job you get paid and rewarded the same way. The year I started, the company RE-instituted a company wide 3% pay raise, which wasn't the worse thing ever.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros: EDMC pays well and I made a lot of good friends  here. Nice building.
cons: Managers and Directors at AI Online gossip about staff. Ground leaders keep getting hired and are making things worse.  It is like high school around here. It is all about who you are friends with.

review_title: Stressful and demanding with low pay.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Most employees are great people who desire to help students succeed. Team spirit. Excellent benefits. PTO. Assisting students with their education goals.
cons:
Management truly wants to do well but are under tremendous pressure from EDMC to chase numbers and make class start dates and quotas. Because of this they are left to micro manage admissions reps and make their lives miserable. There is little potential for upward mobility for admissions reps. As an admissions rep (ADA) you will work 6 days a week (most weeks) and be required to use flex time in leu of overtime. Flex time will be taken when managers determine that office productivity is less likely to suffer. You can expect to spend all day on the phone ( when you are not conducting an office interview or giving a tour) to meet outbound call,  appointment, interview, and application quotas. 

This is a sales job that does not pay commissions and that requires pressuring potential students to enroll and take out large amounts of student loans used to pay tuition, fees, and to ensure EDMC Executives make millions. Because of the restructuring and employee layoffs  at the school it has become difficult for the school to fulfill its promise to students. Additionally, because the admissions department work on a quota system, the students needs are not truly placed first. Management will lip-sync customer care but really wants the ADA's to take the applications and make class starts at all cost (while remaining in compliance of course). 

The admissions department has a high turnover rate. Most successful ADA's will quit within 9 months. Those who can not meet quota consistently, will be fired if they are still around at nine months. This is an extremely stressful working environment. ADA's are nonexempt foot soldiers with no responsibilities other than to: make phone calls, schedule appointments, conduct student interviews, conduct tours, make RSVP quotas for Open House and special events, take required number of applications by gaining student/parent commitment and app fee, and ensuring students show for orientation prepared and ready to start classes. 

ADA's are required to conduct 100 phone calls daily, schedule 12 appointments weekly, conduct 6 interviews weekly, write 3 applications weekly, and meet class start quotas for both mid-quarter and quarter classes. They are also required to ensure 25+ new prospects attend special events weekly. These events are locally and regionally sponsored events such as open house, college information days, and college connection days. Each ADA must obtain 2 applications during these events. Failure to reach the required number usually will result in a 20 minuet berating from your manager once the event has concluded. This type of management serves no purpose other than to make the employee feel lack crap.

review_title: Great people helping others learn and grow despite a stifling and greedy corporate situation
job_title: Faculty in Henderson, NV
pros:
-exposure to technical and artistic creatives in all areas if you work with students or faculty
-networking opportunities amongst students and faculty
-clean well-maintained campus
-students and faculty are a diverse mix
-faculty are great, talented people who truly help students 
-people smile and are friendly and always hold doors for others
cons:
-high student tuition rates wind up paying shareholders- student interests should be first at any school
-some students are admitted who should not be, which is tough on other students and on faculty
-student tuition is not reinvested in the students
-some faculty seem to only teach classes while others are expected to take on many other projects and committees which is not always fair. 
-some of the best employees who have worked there for years and years have been laid off, which is terrible for business. 
-tours are given by Admissions staff that are experienced sales people, they can shovel it deep
-Admissions reps may pressure students to start by a certain date
-Admissions reps may appeal to working class parents' desire to send kids to college to seal deal
-Admissions sells an education that costs much more than UNLV or CSN yet students CAN actually get classes needed to finish Bach in 3 yrs, which won't happen at public colleges. 
-Admissions does not consistently tell students that it will be difficult to transfer credits to another undergrad program or to be accepted to most Master's programs with this degree due to accreditation conflicts (AiLV is nationally accredited) 
-company seems to be on downward spiral if you look at stocks, at pending lawsuits, and at pending regulation that is likely to take down the profitable empire

review_title: You must love cold calling to succeed as an ADA
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Miami, FL
pros: Good team work, the other ADA's (Assistant Director of Admissions) are dedicated and will help you anytime. I found a lot of support from my team when I worked there. The programs were also of good quality with a good combination of academic and practical experience which makes it attractive to students and parents. The fashion program is very well set and the academics and advisors will do their best to help students to succeed.
cons: The training for the job was poor all the way and what they say about the job is nor real. The job is 100% cold calling, and it would be OK if the cold calling was to fresh leads, but it isnt. You must call hundreds of students and no matter what, make them come to the university for an interview and sign up. Many leads are old and they HATE to receive calls from the university, they are tired and upset to keep getting calls, which means when you call again, clients can be very rude. There is a lot of pressure to achieve numbers, and management expects that you achieve your goals by using the same old leads again and again. Also, in many cases, you are asked to lie to people by hiding information from them. Its not right.  When I first started, I was positive and happy to be there, a few months later the bad work environment and the pressure from management for numbers made me take the decision to quit. High turnover and lack of job security is an everyday topic in the corridors.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Denver, CO
pros: Working with art students and in a creative environment. Decent benefits.
cons: High sales pressure tactics to meet unreasonable goals such as pressuring young people into applying to the school and taking out loans they can't afford.  A lot of changes in management because of so much stress from above.

review_title: Good for awhile, but you quickly realize it is not about the students, no matter what corporate says.
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Seattle, WA
pros: The people who work here are excellent. The students produce some of the most creative projects I have ever seen.
cons: Low pay in comparison to local colleges. The school repeatedly cuts programs or classes (most of the time both) for both faculty and students creating a school that is all about they money (though they say they focus on the students.)

review_title: Run... please run away from this abortion of a school!!!
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Brookline, MA
pros: good pay, benefits, nice surroundings in Brookline
cons: High Pressure to Produce Student Starts. Current management talks behind everyone's back! No incentive to do well except to keep management off your back. Unrealistic quotas face Assistant Directors of Admissions since they are not given adequate quality leads to reach their goals.  The system sets up employees to fail. No work / life balance ! STAY AWAY!!!

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Houston, TX
pros:
You get to meet families and students, and you get to help them through their admissions process.
Co-workers are awesome people and fun to work with.
Pay is great.
Benefits are really good, medical, dental and vision, and life insurance.
cons:
Micromanagament especially if you dont make your application goals.
Hours are bad for people that have families.
Needed to work some saturdays each month.
Sales job in the end, can be frustrating when you cannot get the customers you need.

review_title: This job was satisfactory until our department suffered a significant loss due to layoffs. Office was very tense after.
job_title: Financial Aid Officer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Sufficient training; fast-paced environment; team-oriented environment; hands-on involvement with planning and management of student finances
cons: School's valuing of quotas / new-student numbers over retention and best overall interest of students; pressure to produce same amount of work despite 60% departmental cut in workforce;

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great people, interesting atmosphere, working with students, vacation time in between quarters. Faculty genuinely cares about the students and their education.
cons: corporate ruined the name of this school by causing recruiters to do things they shouldn't have, cutting corners, under paying faculty, firing good teachers just because of how much they make, taking in any students they can all just to gain numbers. To them its all about the money.

job_title: Director of Admissions in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The people are great! When working in Sales, there is nothing better than selling a product or service you truly believe in!  Education is something that I truly believe in!
cons: For-profit.  Corporate decision making with little or no local input.  Unorganized.  The industry has recently had very bad public reputation.  Forthcoming regulations and rules that will hurt the industry. In my view, the company is not living up to its mission statement.

job_title: Assistant Dire in Atlanta, GA
pros:
You will meet some people that share the same vision that you have.

Now just offering a work life balance.
cons:
No advancement opportunities-
They grow and promote who they want-
No type of full guidance from management-
The Moral of the team is always down.
No communication when it comes to changes.
Small fish in a big pond-you really half to constantly push through individuals that just want to hear themselves talk.

review_title: Selling an education that doesn't deliver.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Chicago, IL
pros: Good pay, relatively easy job.
cons: Sales driven environment for education, which doesn't make any sense. This is a purely numbers-driven job. The education offered for prospective students should be questioned. Do your research before accepting a job. Company who operates Ai is in numerous lawsuits for questionable advising to prospective students.

review_title: Great company, provides a lot of opportunity for professional grows and excellent  team  of faculty and staff.
job_title: Director of Finance in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Wonderful leadership, great work condition, employees teamwork to help students to find jobs in 6 month after graduation. Corporate (EDMC) offers good benefits, training opportunity and a room to grow..
cons: Company offers a lot of opportunity for personal grows, open door policy to discuss any issue with executive members and see the result of the discussions..

review_title: The people at the local level are a pleasure to work with, but corporate support is near non-existent.
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Nashville, TN
pros:
Co-workers are nice and pleasant. 
In-depth instruction in niche areas not covered by traditional higher education.
Most instructors are passionate about their subjects.
Freedom in creating class structure.
The pay is ok.
Instructors must be "working" professionals.
The equipment is above adequate.
cons:
For-profit institution.
High-turnover rate.
Very few full-time faculty positions. Mostly taught by adjuncts.
Annual reviews are usually 6 to 12 months late.
Is more of a trade focus than a general education.
"Working" professionals includes hobbyists.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Ability to focus on students and their best interests as that relates to a college education.
cons: Consistent fear of employment termination due to the internal motto "you're only as good as your last start". Extremely inconsistent training and coaching in all facets especially for tenured staff.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admission in Chicago, IL
pros: Good entry level sales, marketing, advising role. Alright coworkers but lack of culture and disconnect from other local departments. Good teachers but they're fed up with EDMC.
cons: Poor management. Lack of ethics and HR integration. Disconnect from local campuses and corporate. Extremely poor work environment (poor ventilation/no windows/insects)  and company culture. School looks very institutional/ corporate. Extreme stress. Lack of qualified students.

review_title: Not for the Sound of Mind
job_title: Fulltime Instructor in Los Angeles, CA

Questionable recruitment practices of students and overloaded administration made added to the tense atmosphere and fear based place to work. Eventually very little transparency was left.

review_title: This place is a black hole

review_title: Had an abusive supervisor and the company did nothing to help me with this problem.
job_title: Student Worker in Pittsburgh, PA

job_title: Instructor in Sacramento, CA
pros: Nice building, looks clean and professional from the outside.
