Public praise of the instructors is lip service  Ideas to make the school better are not taken seriously unless they generate money..  The concern about the students is insulting and used as an excuse every time something bad happens.  Management never takes responsibility.

review_title: Great coworkers! Ever changing environment - positive and negative.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The admissions staff are great people, the kind you want to stay in touch with after hours or even after you leave the organization. Passionate and talented students will keep you inspired.
cons: The pressure to grow the school in a difficult economy is immense. Turnover is an issue at all levels of the organization.

job_title: Instructor in Santa Ana, CA
pros: Pays pretty well. You don't have to be an academic superstar to teach there, timing is much more important than the quality of your resume.
cons: Lack of a real process to recruit talented, motivated students produces a lot of failure and very poor outcomes.

review_title: Good Teachers…curriculum and requirements need to be revised
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Good, quality faculty members, and almost ALL are concerned with educating the students. Quite a bit of latitude in exactly what you teach in class. Good feedback system from students you teach. Pay is good.
cons: Some class curricula needs to be revised quite a bit…it's out of date. ALso, classes are assigned to students out of order sometimes, putting more advanced students in classes with beginners.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Houston, TX
pros:
Good starting pay and raise structure
Great people and fun environment
Nice campus to show to prospective students
cons:
Stress creating pressure to bring in students
Knowing lots of students will not succeed and will be in debt with nothing to show for it.
The school attracts students that do not have the drive or resources to stick it out. There are success stories though.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Novi, MI
pros: Salary paying sales job.  Never have to leave the building.  Leads are provided.
cons: Management changes constantly.  Expect you to make 100 calls a day.  The rules change constantly.  Very high turnover.  Very expensive sale.  Financial Aid often does not work for the total amount of tuition.  Sales really does not care about the student, only the sale.

job_title: Junior Web and Graphic Designer in New York, NY
pros: Assisted IT staff with technical issues. Performed reinstallation, software updates and basic troubleshooting on Mac and PC. Supported IT manager with print work, video and editing production.Printed and created posters for staff and students using Photoshop, Illustrator and InDesign.
cons: Down side of this job would be trying trying to satisfy everybody with their issues.  Sometimes issues couldn't be resolved because manager wasn't available at the moment.

review_title: Upside with new ownership-non profit model
job_title: Senior Director of Admissions in Seattle, WA
pros: Opportunity to grow and change lives within organization especially if willing to relocate.  Robust training for Admissions/FA team. Very rewarding to see the transformation in students lives and to support them to graduate.
cons: Due to new leadership and lawsuits, heavy bureaucracy exists without clear goals or strategy to support students/staff. 401k ceased in 2013.

job_title: Instructor in Santa Monica, CA
pros: They don't micromanage.  That's about it.
cons: The overseeing company is increasingly devaluing of our contributions systematically removing our benefits and masking these changes in the worst kind of HR Orwellian double-speak that they must think we're too dim to see through.

review_title: This job, unfortunately, no longer exists.  It was removed via a reorganization after I left.
job_title: Director of Finance in Sacramento, CA
pros: I really enjoyed the people I worked with, and working in a college keeps you young.  Career opportunities were, at one time, very good.  However, that has changed.
cons: The parent company appears to be suffering financial difficulty, which has made the environment very stressful.

job_title: Faculty Member in Atlanta, GA
pros: Working at the Art Institute was fabulous in the 1990's. Their mission statement and actions were about helping students and respecting their employees.
cons: Unfortunately, since the CEO left less than a decade ago and they were purchased by financial institutions, they have lost their vision. They've laid off so many staff and faculty, put no money back into the schools, and leadership lacks effective communication skills. They appear to be laying off all of their full-time faculty in order to bring in lower paid adjuncts who receive no benefits.  Most employees there seem to be interested in finding jobs elsewhere.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Denver, CO
pros: Work with extremely talented and creative students that need direction. Work closely with all facets of the school and direct contact with President of the school if needed. Open door policy about anything you need to discuss.
cons: In my time at the Art Institute of Colorado there was a lot of turnover(ADA's, Directors, Sr. Directors). There were also instructors that were let go that we would highlight when discussing the value of the program and the instructors that you would be working with.

job_title: in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Great students and staff. The best team work I have ever seen.
cons: The worst management. There is no unity and how the company treat employees nationally. So, it is a matter of luck. If you are lucky to have a good immediate supervisor, great. Otherwise, they can do whatever they want.

review_title: working in a library as a student assistant is great!
job_title: Assistant Librarian in San Bernardino, CA
pros:
- Flexible hours
- Friendly staff
- All the food areas are nearby
- you get student discount on their store
- you have all the best sources in school
- work both PC and Macs
- you can bring your own laptop
cons:
- start on minimum wage but you'll get a raise in a year
- not enough hours

review_title: Good campus within an organization that's going through a lot of change
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Ana, CA
pros: The Art Institute of California-Orange County has amazing faculty, staff, and students.  They are a very talented group of people.  Compensation is above industry norm and their facilities are fantastic. Leadership wants to grow the campus.
cons: The Art institutes are going through a lot of change.  It is not uncommon for a new policy or practice to be initiated by corporate with the campus left to figure out the details. Low moral is present.

review_title: Good training but hard core pressure...
job_title: Recruiter in Arlington, VA
pros: There was flexibility with time off but if you are not hitting quota it was very frowned upon to ever take a day off. If you did hit it you would take days off but only to find out you were now behind and had to catch up.
cons: There was way to many clicks, to much pressure to produce and not much trainign. I feel they need to relax on the quota and focus omore on the students and what they need.

job_title: Receptionist Office Work in Frederick, MD
pros: I never took my job for granted!!! It was such a fun and creative atmosphere. I met both new and current students and staff. There was always someone, who needed SOMETHING from our office. I loved my co-workers and honestly, I regret constantly that I had to leave there..
cons: No down time!!! We were always busy, but more so during registration periods. This job can and did get very overwhelming to the wrong person.

review_title: Great potential, but ultimately very disappointing to work here.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in San Francisco, CA
pros: The best part of my job is that I get to help students everyday. My job is never boring. I never know what the day will bring when I interview a student and it feels amazing to know that I am helping people change their lives.
cons: Mangement, work-life ballance, and no perks. Very numbers driven, but you need to have an upbeat attitude 24/7 not matter how hard of a day you are having.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Faculty is solid, professional practitioners. Nice work environment. Parking is excellent and covered.
cons:
Admissions has seats to fill, this is a for-profit school after all.  Some students just need to leave.
Full time faculty numbers are kept to bare minimum for accreditation purposes. Management would probably prefer to only have part-time faculty...save on benefits.

review_title: Great students and faculty, challenging corporate environment
job_title: Academics in Portland, OR
pros: Some really great people teach and work here. While it has fluctuated over the years most if the time there are some very talented students which makes the work very exciting.
cons: The corporate environment takes most of the decision making opportunities away from the people working at the college and therefore one is often in a position of supporting a policy that seems out of step with student need.

review_title: Decent but EDMC shareholder interest will always come before students, faculty and staff.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Arlington, VA
pros: Dedicated professionals almost always at the campus level attempting to help others reach their full potential. Admissions finally cleaned up their act
cons: Corporate entity will always interfere and campus leadership limited or driven by margins rather than service and academics - even if enrollment process is now better, operations (culture) will suffer until the old guard is gone.

job_title: Student Affairs Professional in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
The Students
The Tuition Assistance and Reimbursement Program
The Creative Environment
cons:
There are no real opportunities for growth if you are at a smaller campus
Much of the systems and processes for carrying out specific jobs are not standard across the board so you may have to create those systems (that can actually be a Pro however the pay doesn't necessarily reward you for creating systems etc).

job_title: Instructor in Sacramento, CA
pros: Fun to teach students, great team support, a lot of opportunity for personal growth
cons: Administration is out-of-touch. Unfortunately they'll ignore recommendations and admit a lot of people who just shouldn't be in college, in order to make their numbers and pad their commission. No COLA, no effort to hire more instructors full time. There used to be a great community feel here, but now it's everyone for themselves.

job_title: Career Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Job allows you to help graduating students take the next step which is finding a job that is associated with their degree.
cons: Tough economy/job environment made it quite a challenge to find enough jobs that students/graduates were eligible to apply.

review_title: This place is only good if you do not have any other obligations in life (i.e family, friends, etc)
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: The school is located in the heart of Tribeca and there are always events happening around the workplace. Also the offices itself are not bad.
cons:
- No work/life balance
- Managers/senior management do/does not know how to lead
- No/little room for growth
- Senior management will drive fear into you if you do not do things exactly as they wish
- For admissions, the job is highly numbers driven 
- High stress
- Management turns its back if there is harassment in the workplace

job_title: Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Some of the programs have great instructors that have the knowledge to teach students what employers are looking for. Worked with some talented students which made the job memorable.
cons: Extremely expensive. Before paying a pretty penny, make sure that the student has some talent. Not all Art Institutes are run the same way so do your research on the program and school before deciding.

job_title: Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Department directors readily available.  
Lots of perks (mostly from working in San Francisco)
Good mentoring, staff is very open to helping and talking about issue to help find a solution
Support from other areas is thorough
Very professional attitude.
As flexible as possible considering it is an academic business
cons: Some days its just plain hard work

review_title: It was an ok place to work.
job_title: Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Most of the people were pretty nice and I liked being around the learning environment.
cons: The pay was the biggest con.  Very very low.  And they were pretty stingy with anything that cost money (bonus', time off, and benefits, company get together).  I worked there for about four years.  It was an ok transition job but not where I wanted to work for long.

review_title: Decent Place to work.  Upper leadership out of touch
job_title: Admissions Manager in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
- Great students
- Most people generally want to do the right thing
- Decent Pay
- Benefits available
- 401K match
cons:
- Upper leadership is extremely out of touch with the floor
- Some policies and procedures are ineffective
- No cost of living or merit increases in over a year

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Mason, OH
pros: It's a low hassle job. I come in, teach, and go. There's a regular meeting with my immediate boss once a week, but otherwise I'm anonymous.
cons: It's a for-profit school. They don't care about educating the students. The company cares about extracting money from working class kids and veterans.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Cincinnati, OH
pros: AI is a good place to work. Competent and professional management, great support, up-to-date equipment and facilities. Management is very supportive of the faculty and staff.
cons: The problem common to all proprietary education - the admission of some under-qualified students who simply shouldn't be in college.

review_title: They did a good job of providing on-the-job-training.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Denver, CO
pros: The benefits are good. The salaries were more than fair. Your production dictates your salary, so if you work hard and succeed, you will be paid for it.
cons: Only thing admissions cares about is getting applications and starting students. They do not care about the student or if it is a good fit. Too concerned about numbers. Expect you to work a ton of weekends and late evening hours. Not concerned about employee work life balance.

review_title: It was great when I was hired but in 5 years it steadily declined to intolerable.
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in San Bernardino, CA
pros: My co-workers were all great.  Even my immediate management.  There were lots of training opportunities.  Senior management at the location was very accessible, tho not responsive.
cons: Corporate policies from Pittsburgh, PA dictate everything.  When the corporation isn't making money, you can expect a lot of take-aways.  Year after year, things got worse.  Pay is low to start with and raises are infrequent and small.  Virtually no benefits for part-timers, the majority of the faculty.  The demands placed on faculty got greater every year.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great team of people to work with.  It is wonderful to be able to work with the students.
cons: no job security. Management is all about the bottom line. I live in constant fear of losing my job

job_title: Academic Department Chair in Indianapolis, IN
pros: There are some great employees here and the programs have fantastic potential as well.
cons: There has not been enough investment back into the campuses which causes frustration and dissatisfaction. Students are paying a lot of money to attend here but do not see how that investment is directly contributing to their experience. Biggest con is the mismanagement over the years that has led to the recent closing of 3/4 of the campuses across the country.  It is a shame.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Austin, TX
pros:
* Aesthetically appealing environment of student, community, and faculty work.
* Great food in dining lab/restaurant open to public that is serviced by culinary students.
* Sounds cool to say "I work for The Art Institute of Austin."
cons:
* It is all about selling and enrolling students into the next start date (every five weeks).
* The focus is not really on student's success, but getting them in school.
* Turnover is high in admissions and financial aid departments because of stress put on employee's to meet sales quota.
* Micromanagement!
* In admissions department you are not compensated for the sales person you are with commission or incentives for meeting goals.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Durham, NC
pros: Very helpful staff. Solid technology in the classroom (worked at the Durham, NC location). They had solid security throughout the site. Overall a enjoyable place to work. Was there for 3 months.
cons: It would have been better is there was more curriculum for the course I taught. They left it up to each teacher to sculpt their own materials if they wanted. I thought it would be better to have a set curriculum, but that was not the case.

review_title: Great co-workers, but horrible job design for admissions.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Houston, TX
pros: Great co-workers and free food whenever breakfast/lunch was catered.
cons: Job design.  They say it is not a "sales" job, but you are required to start a certain number of students per quarter, regardless if they were a good fit for the school or not.  The last year I was there, they said they couldn't give any raises for the following year due to financial cuts, etc.  Low employee morale.

review_title: Not accommodating or flexible to employees with families.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in San Francisco, CA
pros: The programs and close community supporting the student to succeed.  I like the collaborative effort to assist the student with internships and polished portfolios and resume.
cons: It's been 8 years since I worked here and back then the policy was very rigid about taking time off within two weeks of a start date.  Was not at all a family friendly place to work.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Portland, OR
pros: Great starting pay for people in admissions. Great benefits overall. Some great people to work with.
cons: This place is going under fast, horrible turnover and under appreciated employees. Has got away from core positive values and are strictly now about the numbers and recruiting.

review_title: Good educational institution in the midst of a precipitous decline due to corporate foolishness.
job_title: Instructor in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great faculty and educational support, current technology, on the leading edge of visual design, student success is excellent for those who craft a solid portfolio.
cons: The faculty and students often feel like corporate puppets, waiting for decisions about academics to be determined based on various "indicators" but yet the faculty are rarely consulted for their input. Sad.

review_title: A decent employer on-campus that offers a nice supplement to income
job_title: Sales Associate in Seattle, WA
pros:
- on-campus
- flexible schedule
- great staff

The supply store at the Art Institute of Seattle (where I was employed) was a great job, and definitely a nice change of pace from just going to school and going home to work on homework every day.
cons:
- Not many hours
- No benefits 

Sadly, we were only ever given around 10 hours a week. Nowhere NEAR enough to live off of, and no real benefits to speak of.

job_title: Administrative in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Really smart, fun people at the local level. People who are passionate about students and their success.
cons: Corporately all over the place and it is touch for the schools to keep up.  A new initiative every week - with expectations of immediate results - but poor implementation in almost every case.

job_title: Gen Ed Indstrictor in Chicago, IL
pros: Quarter schedule at AI can fill holes between semesters at other schools. Dept heads are nice, deans are okay (typical bosses). Students make it special - this is a different crowd than a community college!
cons: Salary is okay, limit to number of classes assigned per year. AI faculty needs a union real bad!

job_title: Paper Conservation in Chicago, IL
pros: Great museum and wonderful learning experience. Plus, a great city to live in. Location is wonderful.
cons: Pay is very low. Very high work load. Had to fix work of long term staff and I was just a fellow. higher ups did not appreciate the hard work you do. The overall employee satisfaction is very low and never get raises.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Austin, TX
pros: Get to actually make a difference in people's lives. Amazing Benefits. Good work/life balance, never work outside a set schedule of mandatory overtime.
cons: Management is challenging to communicate with and does not lead by example. You are expected to understand far more than is actually given to you. Support staff is overworked. Other departments do not respect this department. There is not much in the way of good leadership.

review_title: Great flexibility, faculty. Senior management out of touch. Questionable recruiting tactics
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Working with students eager to learn, flexible schedule. Access to useful software.
cons: Top down management style, not particularly interested in hearing what's happening on the ground. Not much academic freedom. Just cut 401k matching plan, the only benefit for adjunct instructors. No raises after several years' experience. Must supply own computer.

job_title: Professor in Brookline, MA
pros: Decent pay and health plans, local (campus) management excellent. There's a 20 word minimum for this section.
cons: Some executive in Pittsburgh thinks he can run a college in Boston, but is completely out of touch with the local challenges. It's also hard to accept being told that you can't order a new printer for your students when the CEO brought home $15M in bonuses the year before.

review_title: My overall experience working for AIA has been enjoyable.
job_title: Student Tutor in Dunwoody, GA
pros: Great co-workers, probably because we all have the same goal in mind. Being able to help students who may be having difficulty in certain areas of their education.
cons: Upper management lacks people skills and doesn't seem to put the extra effort into their attitudes or drive to get better.

job_title: Instructor in San Diego, CA
pros: AI San Diego is a great place to work overall.  We have strong staff development programs and strictly follow WASC accreditation procedures to support a strong staff....love the staff, love the students, updated curriculum, strong technology
cons: There are very few cons I have a commute, we need  higher enrollment, but benefit from smaller class sizes which supports strong overall learning for students and instructors...overall it is very good

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Dallas, TX
pros: The benefits are great if you have a family.  The President of the college cares and truely has an open door policy.  He and the school care about our success and want to help us get there.  They assist rather than demand.
cons: Pay is only ok. (40s) to start and I'm hearing there were no raises last year.

review_title: Best Job I Had in College
job_title: Student Support | Color Rasterization Specialist in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Flexible hours - ability to work on schoolwork while working in the lab.  Learned a ton about IT support fundamentals.  Provided an additional avenue to interface with faculty.  Great pay at the time.
cons: Provided almost no division between work time and class time...any time you were in the building, you were approachable with student or faculty issues.  Faculty would also use class time to register complaints about services.

review_title: Difficult company to feel good about working for
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Austin, TX
pros: Starting pay and benefits are good, schedule is good, it's fun to get to know the students
cons: Poor management, difficult product to feel good about selling - company is aggressive and predatory to potential students- especially those from low incomes who may qualify for the most grant/loan money.  $80-100k for a so-so education plus the promise of being in debt for the rest of your life is a difficult sell.

review_title: Recruitment and sales in for-profit higher education
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Cincinnati, OH
pros: You get to make a positive impact on the lives of young people going from high school to college, as well as non-traditional students returning to college, who want to pursue a creative career in commercial arts.
cons: The financial stability of the organization had negative impacts on the students and the faculty/staff.

job_title: Lead IT Technician in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I worked with a couple of great people, and most understood resources were always slim. Insurance benefits were great when I worked there, I have learned that has gone away.
cons: Resources were always slim.  There is a reason this company is always facing lawsuits.  They either get rid of all their good employees or they chase them away with terrible policies.

review_title: AIP is a case study in the incompatibility of for-profit and education.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Daily contact with talented teachers and prospective students.
cons: Too legion to list: unethical management that habitually breaks laws; abuse of admissions staff; horrible work-life balance; flight and firing of veteran instructors; culture of fear among faculty and staff; hotbed of gender, age, and race discrimination; financial victimization of students.

job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Chicago, IL
pros: Students who otherwise would have no option to go to school have an open door to higher education.
cons: Compensation was weak, organizational structure is top heavy and chaotic. Looking only to stay afloat versus long term student success.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Chicago, IL
pros: Presentation skills and sales skills can be developed but not in a consultative manner, definitely old-school hard close.
cons: This institution is not concerned with the value to the students but much more focused on making sales number in the form of enrolling students on the spot.  Very little preparation or metrics used in enrolling students.  Management uses intimidation and fear rather than positive reinforcement or professional development for their staff.

job_title: Art Director in Cincinnati, OH
pros: If you are an independent learner who has the drive to make it on their own, you might pick up one or two things from a teacher if you talk to them outside class. But if you're an independent learner, you'll soon realize you never should have signed up.
cons: They lie to you about success rates and former students to get you to enroll. Then once you're in your classes, you realize the teachers don't even want to be there.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Denver, CO
pros: You get to take classes, and if anything they teach there interests you you can attend events and pretty much participate in anything you want
cons: High pressure sales environment, unethical tactics to get students to enroll, working late nights and weekends, cold calling people who don't want to go to school there

review_title: Lots of Pressure to Get People to Sign the Dotted Line
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Lots of creative people everywhere! Fun students, great facility. Giving campus tours were easily the highlight.
cons: You're expected to follow a sales script to get prospective students to enroll. It's expensive, and you're pushing young people to take on tremendous debt. No opportunity for advancement whatsoever.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Nashville, TN
pros: The company allows you to be you.  It's a open community for GLBT. The pay is very competitive and the benefits are great.
cons: The job is not for someone married or with children.  The sales side of it makes it very challenging to do a quality job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Nashville, TN
pros: laid back atsmosphere. Pay is pretty good. Get paid holidays and sixteendays of personal time which is good. Good Benefits
cons: Pressured into starting students that aren't good canadites. Endless cylce of putting more kids into debt. Finaancial Aid only covers the tip of the iceburg if they can even qualify for grants. Then have to make payments to the shcool plus student loans.

job_title: Student Worker in Austin, TX
pros: As a student worker on campus, you're guaranteed to have a work schedule that will not interfere with your class schedule. Other employers wouldn't be as understanding or flexible.
cons: The only downside is the pay rate of $8/hr with a maximum of 20 hrs per week. However, since the position is paid from the Federal Workstudy program I can't fault the school.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros: Decent pay. People are friendly that work there.
cons: No realistic growth opportunities unless you know someone well in upper management.  Not consistent with managers.  Pretty much at the same time, managers were "stepping down for personal reasons" and being replaced.  I guess it was better to say that then saying being demoted.  One particular manager advised my thoughts were correct.  Poor metric system

review_title: No Room for Opportunities to Move Up
job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Atlanta, GA
pros: High pay for this position, 401k, dental, health, vision, life, short and long term benefits. Hours of Operation 9 am to 7 pm.
cons: Lots of favoritism. Seniority Rules over  Hard Work and Skill.  Saturday Shifts. Dealing with a group that doesn't market well. Company instability.

review_title: The Art Institute is a Con
job_title: Instructor in Seattle, WA
pros: The views out the window are  great
cons: The president of the school has no interest in ART or the success of students. This school is about making money, a lot of money from low income and military people. Beware. There are some great instructors but the focus is not to prepare the students for the continual evolving business world of art. There computer equipment is just passable. The projection screens they use in the class room are awful. They try to teach color and light theory but fail miserably.

job_title: in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Opportunities for promotion
working for the arts
Helping students
Free or low-cost education and decent benefits for employees
Great 401K plan
cons:
Gaps in communication between management and employees
Incompetence is often rewarded at the local level
Some of the staff/faculty can be high-strung

review_title: Lack of resources for both students and staff for expensive prices
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Arlington, VA
pros: There is flexibility but you will find yourself working alot. even on holidays and weekends.
cons: training, goals, resources, attitudes of staff. and the health insurance plan is not the best plus you  have to pay high prices to park at work.

review_title: Most unethical place I have ever worked
job_title: Admissions in Miami, FL
pros: Great colleagues who you can vent with
cons:
I worked at MIU for 6 years and at first it was a great job... Then it started getting really bad.  I was in admissions and we were required to enroll a specific amount of students, get a certain amount of $50 applications, and now they added on a requirement of three enrollment from personally developed references. If you don't perform, you're fired.

We were told during that summer was the perfect chance to get new students who couldn't get into other colleges and those students were constantly called "low hanging fruit"
The crime reports are false - they do not show any listings for an assault on campus in 2014 even though police were called and police reports filed.  EDMC is only concerned for themselves, not the students futures or safety. Only after the incident did MIU alter safety measures.  They had meetings with both faculty and staff to go over the incident and new safety rules, so it's beyond me why it was left off of the crime report. I'm sure if confronted about it, the dean of student affairs would just say it was overlooked. Really
There are very few full time staff because EDMC doesn't want to pay for insurance and other full time benefits. As a result, some of the best and most instructors were either laid off or quit.
The guilt I started feeling because I was talking students into enrolling in a school that has so many worthless programs of study, was staggering. I felt I was involved in an illegal and unethical scam that just put students in a large amount of debt for such worthless programs.
Some legitimate art schools usually require a portfolio of your work to see if you are talented enough to get into certain art programs.  MIU doesn't care if you can't even draw.  They just want you in school.  Also check out the retention rates - they show how many people have dropped out.
The stress working there was not worth the $60,000 salary I received.

review_title: Failing school/organization. In need of restructuring
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Arlington, VA
pros: Salary is more competitive than for profit education institutions in the local Northern Virginia & D.C. market
cons: Failing organization. Poor management.  Quick turn over. Shrinking team and support system due to lay offs. No 401k matching.

review_title: Good environment, diverse students, but could be better
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Miami, FL
pros: Faculty develop their own lesson plans, department chair is extremely engaged and supportive
cons: This Ai location has been affected by the negative publicity from the closing of other locations around the country, even though Miami is a top performing school in fashion and design.

review_title: I was a faculty member for over eight years.
job_title: Instructor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Initially, it was great to work with students who were passionate and excited over their futures. There is a lot of autonomy for instructors, decent pay.
cons: The corporation that owns Ai has destroyed it. The students are rarely passionate, there is no morale on campus, and no emphasis on quality education.

review_title: It's a ok company to work for.
job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: I have job security. Supervisor is relax on time off request.
cons: There is no structure. Information is inconsistent from Corporate. No opportunity for growth or advancement unless you are willing to relocate. Compensation for the amount of work is not bad but its not good either. Its enough to keep you coming back.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros: They paid me a lot of money to dial and smile on the phone.
cons: Piss-Poor management. old business model outdated and we use 1980's technology. There is no ramp up time and you are expected to hit your numbers but the problem with that is we can't talk about number so that mean you have to enroll students.

job_title: in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Pays the bills
Improve up on sales skills
Not physically demanding
Training is provided and management is patient will employees learn the business
cons:
Always on the phone and making calls
Have to weed through to serious canidates, often being hung up on
Pay can be cut every six months after 18 month anniversity

review_title: The ship is sinking at all The Art Institutes!
job_title: Career Services Advisor in Portland, OR
pros: The students who are there trying and trusting they can obtain an education there. Some of the faculty.
cons: Telemarketing is the main activity for advisors, not building personal relationships within the industry because all the focus is on HOW MANY phone calls are made per day. There are mandatory quotas, and it has become busy work that prevents advisors from doing their work and bring their professionalism to students and the industry. The career services staffs everywhere have been reduced to so few advisors per school that students are not provided anything close to the kind of career assistance they've been promised when they enrolled, and students are paying a very high cost of education there. One of the selling points of attending the Art Institutes was that in the past, before all the ruthless employee cuts were made, students were provided with specialized advisors who knew their industries, and who networked in real ways, in person and at industry events, as well as phone and email, to build a base of employers who hired the students. Now phones in advisors offices are bugged to make sure the advisor is making the mandatory number of calls per day, as if they're selling magazines. It's become a horrible depressing place to work, and most of the good people in career services have left even if they weren't downsized out. .

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Nearly everyone in the Admissions team is so miserable that it actually evokes common unity.
cons:
No Commission whatsoever and your quotas are difficult to meet. If you do meet your quotas you are rewarded with even higher quotas making the job even more difficult without an incentive to want to do better. 

This job will consume your entire life. You work a lot of weekends. The weeks are mentally and physically draining. You often end up working over 8 hours to meet your numbers. They do not do overtime. The last thing you want to do is work on a Saturday. Even though they say its only two weekends a month, realistically its more like 3 and sometimes 4 weekends a month.

The company culture has become very toxic for the last 5 years. Nearly everyone in nearly every department hates working there and as soon as they get an opportunity to leave they typically do and with a skip on their way out. 

The promotion system is incredibly vague and very much based on word of mouth and favoritism. Its highly preferenced towards females. If you are a male, you will not be taken seriously. Its very much a good ole' Gals Club. Advice for males with terrific managerial experience: Begin seeking employment elsewhere. If you don't wear lipstick and six inch heals to work everyday, your chances for promotion are slim to none. 

All and all, if you are desperate enough, this job will suffice, but mark my words you will never get comfortable. You will constantly be on the hot skillet. Get to cracking and make those numbers!

review_title: Pros and Cons of Working there.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Shorewood, WI
pros: Faculty and staff are dedicated to the education of their student.
cons: EDMC Corporate office has a very poor and unethical  business model. Due to their business practice they are shutting down half of their schools across the U.S. Faculty not treated well with heavy teaching loads added to to teach outs. There basic benefits such as health insurance is sub par and they have now stopped 401 k matching. To cut cost the corporate office will fire staff and faculty based on unfounded rumors and conjecture.

review_title: The Art Institute of Austin is interested in numbers and mediocrity.
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Austin, TX
pros:
* Plenty of opportunities to build up your teaching portfolio and get lots of classes on your resume.
* Relative autonomy (depending on your academic director)
* Lots of other great faculty to work with
cons:
* The executive committee (including the revolving door of "presidents" who often don't even have masters degrees)
* A general sense that the students are much more important than the faculty. This seems great in theory, but doesn't work when it means we have students that should not be enrolled and the faculty are just told to bend over and deal with them.
* If you want to stick around long, you will teach year-round. This is very difficult because AI is on a quarter schedule and other schools in the area use semesters. Good luck paying your bills.
* Constant schedule fluctuations. This means that one quarter you'll have a great schedule, and the next it will be completely upended, not allowing you to do any outside work.
* Did I mention poor upper management?
* Terrible facilities and equipment. Unbelievable for an institution that charges students $90,000 for a bachelor's degree.
* Budgets are always problematic at institutions of higher education, but it's absurd how bad it is at AI.
* Nothing can be changed in the overall curriculum without approval from the Houston campus. Approval = them modifying their curriculum as well. There is no campus autonomy in this respect.

For the money they pay, our students should have access to top-notch everything, and they don't even have the best in the Austin area. That's pretty stunning.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chicago, IL
pros: You have the opportunity to meet some very talented students, location is great and pay is comparable to other schools in the area.
cons: The company only cares about the bottom line and not the students. Career growth opportunities are poor. Management does not have foresight.

review_title: If you want to sell your soul, work here!
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good pay, benefits & some of the best co-workers I could ever had asked for. Your co-workers here are some of the best people you will have ever met because you understand what each other's going thru and the tremendous amount of stress and ridiculous demands of management. When your own family can't even fathom the thought of it being 1/2 as bad as your explaining, your co-workers understand 100%.
cons:
First of all, you get sold a dream. It seems all good at first , because the pay is great and so are the benefits. Once you realize it is indeed a sleaze bag sale job and not even 1 in 5 student's belong there, and you work every Saturday for 6 weeks and get tortured for being 5 minutes late because you commute an hour and have work 6 days a week for the past 6 weeks, GET NO INDEPENDENCE BUT MICRO-MANAGED, you would rather pay them a 100 dollars just to have a day off. When you realize the money is not worth it, you either get stuck there because you literally have no time spend time with your significant other let alone find a new job or you wasted time there. 
When these reviews say, the management is unethical etc., that's an understatement. It's truly a glorified telemarketing job in a sweat shop and your selling a 100,000.00$ education to a student who cant even write a 150 word essay to be accepted! But do not fear because management will re-write it or have you do it, to force more student's in the door!!!! Stay away!!! I feel bad for my friends that are still stuck there! Oh yeah and that bullS*** about 6% raises annually. LOL...BULLS***!!! They laid of half of the academic staff, financial aid, registrar, translator's and so on. So just when you thought you were signing up for a sales or customer service position, you have became an admissions rep, a financial officer, a registrar (you have to literally register the student's) NEED I GO ON? This is coming form someone who over sat every class, exceeded every goal and worked there for a few years. I won't even continue to tell you about politics there, it will only make me throw-up. I hope you reading this will encourage you not to take the position, because I promise you WILL regret it.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Houston, TX
pros: The admissions staff is great and the staff in general is very friendly and approachable.  You get to work with a lot of nice people who are, in most cases, genuinely interested in helping students.  Some students are truly gifted/ talented.  The Houston campus is very nice in terms of the equipment and resources offered to students.
cons:
Too many to list here.  This is a for-profit college, which means that nothing is considered useful unless it directly correlates with money.  Everything and everyone that's not absolutely essential has been cut.  

No overtime pay for Saturdays worked.  The "expectation" is that you leave early the next Tuesday so that your hours never exceed 40.  And you will work 2-3 Saturdays every month.  Along with 2-3 nights that you're in the office until 7 or 8 every week.

No one thinks you're working unless the work is quantifiable.  Emails don't count.  Office work doesn't count.  The only thing that counts is how many phone calls, interviews, applications, and starts you had for a given amount of time.  Then do it all over again tomorrow because what you did today won't count anymore.  

High turnover.  No genuine concern for the staff or the students.  Lots of fake enthusiasm.  Students are almost forced to start during whenever the next start is, even if the classes already started.  Wanna drop and add/drop already passed?  Sorry.  You now owe the school money.  Even if you were only in class once or twice.

Some students are very creative and maybe should be in an arts school.  Many students "think" they're creative, but are really just lost and/or lazy.  You get to call and harass all off them all day long.

Not really much opportunity for advancement at the campus level.

There isn't much integrity left, there's definitely no respect, and it's probably going to keep getting worse.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Santa Monica, CA
pros: Great support from management and academic affairs.  Rewarding and fulfilling career working with creative students.  On-going training helps refresh skills.
cons: Corporate struggles cause uncertainty and feelings of instability among staff and faculty.  This particular campus is closing as soon as all enrolled students complete their degree.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Austin, TX
pros: Love the students and colleagues.
cons: Aloof and out of touch management. Questionable admission practices sometimes fill classes with students who are not college-ready, and faculty is held accountable for students for poor student performance. There are really no incentives in place to reward good classroom experiences. Mediocre instruction is regarded the same as creative and effective instruction. Continued restructuring erodes morale.

review_title: If you like being bossed around by Admissions reps, work here!
job_title: in Dallas, TX
pros: Excellent benefits, PTO, tuition, holidays, etc.
cons:
Management is completely incompetent. They are extremely petty, and depending on who you're under you will be treated like a child and nit picked on all day (even if you're smarter and brighter than your superior). Several (more than 3 in one dept) have quit on this reason alone. Oh yeah and HR works for the management so don't expect any help there...

BEWARE, if you work in Admissions, be prepared to try to reach unreachable goals. The school is having trouble making their class start goals, so when there's trouble there, employees suffer. Admissions reps walk around like they own the place when they are REPLACED every year. That position is a revolving door. New faces all the time and no one knows how to do their job. Training? LOL

Financial aid is horrid. There is no proper procedure. The financial aid officer calls the students as if they're the student's admissions rep. If you work in financial aid you WILL be doing admissionsy type work (without the pay or better increases), and you WILL be calling and hounding students to complete their paperwork (more than their Admissions rep will). You will also be seeing students who have little to no paperwork and putting together financial aid plans. Team work? Forget about it. Everyone is in it for themselves. Don't let someone take a long break or lunch...you'll be seeing students BACK TO BACK. Managers have NO (and I'm not exaggerating) competence.

The goal is to get students in the door NO MATTER WHAT. The president claims that they do what is in the best interest of the student, but they don't. Getting someone in debt for $30k+ for them to only drop out because they weren't a fit or academically up to par is in the best interest of the student? Okay. Prepare to question your ethics and morals. It's a numbers game bottom line.

And job security? There is definitely NONE for admissions, and they make cuts at random due to organization restructuring. So if they're doing bad, expect some cuts, and it could be you!

If you work here, try going into administration. Not admissions or financial aid. Good luck and God bless! I would never go back...

review_title: Fun for entry-level pros; however, no room for growth.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Arlington, VA
pros: Fun working in a creative/artsy environment.
cons: EDMC is a for-profit educator with only numbers on their minds. Corporate rides the directors, who in turn ride you. Instead of having the students best interests at heart, they put them in debt when most of them shouldn't be in college in the first place. They market to the wrong individuals.

review_title: Excited for the students in the STL area to have this opportunity!

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Phoenix, AZ

cons: Unethical when it comes to recruiting techniques. Inquiries are paper and only given to a select few. HIGH turn over.

review_title: It just kept getting worse...former Admissions Employee
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Central location in SF, good for commuting inside and outside of the city. 
PTO/Benefits/401k matching are good.
cons: The location is less than desirable since it is overrun with transients and drug addicts.  Demoralizing work conditions. Inability to take days off (even though you get a decent amount of PTO).   Work hours are insane and weekends and late nights are mandated.

review_title: May the odds be every in your favor....
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Atlanta, GA
pros: Good pay, good benefits, awesome coworkers.
cons:
HIGH PRESSURE / MICROMANAGE / LOW MORALE / HIGH TURNOVER / AWFUL HOURS / ETC. ETC.

I can't speak for other departments, but Admissions is pretty bad and very comparable to the movie Hunger Games. On top of being handed unattainable goals that seem to continuously increase, you also have management constantly reminding you of how you're not doing enough--no positive feedback or recognition. They also micromanage to an unbearable point, send threatening emails, make you fear you could lose your job, constantly changing forms or procedures, etc. Then they try to blame the negativity and low morale on the employees instead of looking at themselves or finding a way to correct it. Also, they speak very demeaning to employees and practically treat us like children at times. They truly do not listen to employees concerns or suggestions. They use aggressive bullying tactics to try to get certain people to quit or eventually fire them and it works. I've seen roughly 30+ people leave or get fired in the year so there's the high turnover. Also, they have changed the scheduling around so that is NOT condusive to family life. They try to pretend all these changes are "company wide" yet we're the only campus doing them in comparison to nearby AIs.

I know other campuses aren't this bad, so it's not necessarily the job itself. You are on the phone a lot daily recruiting students then interviewing and enrolling them. If the goals weren't so high, it'd be pretty easy and enjoyable. I truly like working with students and helping them, but the environment in admissions has made me feel beat down on a daily/weekly basis.

review_title: A joke for adjuncts. Heck, a joke for all the grunts.
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Austin, TX
pros: The best part about working for Ai-Austin is the ability to use the facilities (whether this is explicitly allowed or not) and equipment to build your own portfolio, and of course, the opportunity to teach. I took advantage of the system the entire time I was there, and I'm glad I did. Beating their inane system allowed me to propel myself into a tenure-track position at an R1 university.
cons:
The pay is not good. $44 was my starting hourly teaching rate in 2009, and was only up to $46 in 2014, which doesn't even keep pace with inflation. At one time, classes were somewhat plentiful, and I taught an average of 16-20 classes a year. This was far too heavy a teaching load, but afforded me the ability to make more money. My final year, it was constantly threatened that our classes would be capped at 3 per quarter, resulting in a rough salary of $24k/year. I believe the most I ever made was still under $40k/year.

The school has a very corporate-driven atmosphere, and the best thing you can do is keep your head down and just do the bare minimum that's expected. If you're hoping to move up in academia to a real university (this is NOT a real university — let's be clear), then I would recommend adjuncting anywhere else while you're at Ai, because Ai alone won't look good on your CV.

The students are completely unaware of how poorly their teachers are compensated, and thus act like you should be at their beck and call. The bad students, that is. There are occasionally outstanding students that really don't belong at such a terrible institution, and sometimes I told them just that. Thankfully, many of them heeded my advice. I consider some of them friends and peers today. Other students that didn't show as much promise stuck it out and actually grew substantially as well, but most students admitted to the school shouldn't be there. Their writing skills are particularly atrocious.

I can't see this school surviving long-term, but I guess with the massive influx of new Austin residents, there will always be naive students (and faculty) for the school to prey on. They're just lucky that the market is absolutely FLOODED with qualified MFAs, and thus they always have a steady supply of potential teachers. To those teachers, I say: Do what you gotta do, but get out as soon as you can. I'm glad I did.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: good health insurance.  Not much else I could say. Worst working environment/conditions of my entire career.
cons: Every single thing about this place is a con. You will be over worked underpaid 6 out of 7 days a week. This job is decorated with pretty words of integrity, but in actuality you are a car dealer with no commission. Pressured beyond means to shove a 100,000 dollar tuition down a un knowing student's throat. I'm not sure what's worse, what you are actually contributing to in this role, or the toxic work environment itself or the pure exhaustion you will feel working the most insane hours every day in unrealistically high pressure. This organization should be investigated. Simply horrible. Corporate should be ashamed of themselves.

job_title: Academic Advisor in Atlanta, GA
pros: Lots of locations, good group of people in my office. Seemed like there was always something to do. Easy access to public transportation as well.
cons: Long hours, lots of students, little regard for personal life. The quality of students is not good either, if you come from an environment with more academically engaging students.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: You have health benefits, guaranteed pay raises and tuition assistance (if you choose to take it).
cons: Where do I begin? As far as the above, I felt I had to say something nice, however please take those with a grain of salt. One, the medical insurance costs a ton, two, for what you're making it isn't worth the stress that comes with it and three, the degree there won't get you anywhere. This place is a joke. For those who are hard workers, have a family and sanity in your life, this isn't the place for you. Not only does everyone leave who has been there but the people who stay are power hungry and have no life but to try and bring you down to their level. The place is FULL of drama, immature employees and they do nothing to try and make you happy. They wonder why the student body has dropped and people are miserable and have no desire to come to work. If you want to make sure it isn't just this campus, look at ALL the other campuses and company review for validation. It's only getting worse and they are doing absolutely nothing to change it. I would even consider stepping into this college for an interview, unless you're desperate, don't mind working stupid shifts, Saturday's and can't even have a paper plate to heat up your lunch.

job_title: Foundations Faculty in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The school had an excellent program for developing artistic careers and had excellent Faculty and students

review_title: The Art Institute of Austin WAS Great
job_title: Web and Graphic Design Professor in Austin, TX
pros: Have a lot of freedom of what and how you teach.  The people who work there, besides upper management are amazing.  The schedule was good, five courses a quarter was easily managed.
cons: The Art Institutes were bought out by the Dream Center out in Los Angeles and now they have decided it best to fire all the full time faculty for cheap adjunct labor which hurts everyone in the long run.  Our campus was doing fine, we had enough students, our numbers were going up, but they still decided to throw all the full time faculty away like trash.  People have essentially lost their jobs and students won't get full time faculty working for them.  Was there for two years and never got a raise, the health care was expensive and not very good, there was no retirement matching or anything like that, all in all, the benefits weren't very appealing.  Part time pay is about $1800  per course which really isn't that great.  I adjunct at other places that pay around $3000 so Ai's offering is pretty pathetic.  With the way they are going, I don't see the campus surviving.  Students are going to freak out when they find out their full time faculty that they've gotten to know and love are not longer going to be working there because I know for a fact I'm not staying.  Why would I want to work somewhere that doesn't value me and considers my contributions worthless?

review_title: Terrible company to work for, doesn't value employees or students
